column2: Mordecai Katz continued: During the separation a rumor was spread that my daughter was faithless to her husband. The source of the rumor is still a mystery to me. My son-in-law then produced a document of some obscure court which accused her of behaving in the most licentious manner with X. I do not know who the judges of the court were. My daughter was not summoned to appear before the court. The witnesses who testified against her are known in the city to be unreliable, disreputable, and irresponsible persons. I then turned to Rabbi I. Sterenberg, to Rabbi Isaac Stengly, and to Rabbi Meir Bern, to try the case before them. But when my son-in-law was summoned, he refused to appear…. Mordecai then produced a document signed by the three rabbis of the court that Zeligman had refused to appear upon a summons before their court.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).26
column2: Did the court that convicted your wife serve her with a summons?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).27
column2: No, it did not serve her with any summons.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).28
column2: Why did the court not serve her?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).29
column2: Because she lost her right to defend herself on account of her father. He exercised so much influence in the city that everybody feared him, and no witness would dare to testify in her presence. Therefore I tried the case in her absence.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).30
column2: Why did you refuse to appear before the court of Rabbi Sterenberg, Rabbi Isaac Stengly, and Rabbi Meir Bern?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).31
column2: For the same reason I stated before. I thought that no court would venture to convict her in her presence.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).32
column2: The defense presents witnesses to disqualify the testimony of A and B:

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).33
column2: A informed the government against the leaders of the city of Prague while they were assembled in their meeting-place.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).34
column2: While the leaders of the community of Prague were meeting at their headquarters, A informed the government against them. (Witness II delivered his testimony in the absence of Zeligman, because the latter had left for Prague.)

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).35
column2: A threatened to inform the government on certain people and to kill them. (A number of witnesses testified to the same thing.)

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).36
column2: A swears all the time. He blasphemed the name of God many times and always mentions the name of other gods.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).37
column2: Stolen books were found in B's house.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).38
column2: B stole from me many times. One stolen article I found at the goldsmith's who bought it from him.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).39
column2: I remember that years ago when I was still a minor B stole things from my father.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).40
column2: My landlord told me that B is a suspicious character and a thief.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).41
column2: The defense produces evidence that Zeligman was looking for false witnesses:

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).42
column2: Zeligman has been running after me for a long time, and he offered me a note of ten dollars in order to testify that I saw his wife in X's house, and there they…. He told me that he had secured many signatures from witnesses to this effect, and asked me to sign the same paper. When I looked at the paper I noticed all the names were of the same handwriting. I refused to sign it.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).43
column2: The defense produces testimony to refute the evidence offered by the plaintiff:

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).44
column2: During my sickness Zeligman paid me a visit. He left four dollars on the table and said: "Take the four dollars and buy yourself jewelry, and when you get well testify for me." When I recovered from my illness I returned the four dollars. Shortly after that I planned to move to another place; his brother-in-law sent for me and asked me to give him the testimony asked for by Zeligman in writing. At first I refused, but when he told me that he would not return the pledges I had pawned with him I changed my mind and wrote down everything he dictated! But I think that my testimony will not do him any good, because I gave it to him in the absence of any court.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).45
column2: Signed: SOLOMON BEN ELIEZER ZELKIND

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).46
column2: They wanted that my wife too should testify for them but since she did not know Miriam at all, they pleaded with her to say that everything I wrote was true.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).47
column2: Signed: SOLOMON BEN ELIEZER ZELKIND

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).48
column2: If I would want to sin, I could have made a lot of money; Zeligman wanted to hire me as a witness.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).49
column2: Zeligman was running after me for weeks in succession, offering me money to persuade my wife to testify that she saw Miriam and X misbehaving. But I refused to sell my soul for money.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).50
column2: The testimony of all the witnesses exhibited by the defense is no ground to disqualify A and B as witnesses, because they were not present when the evidence against them was given.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).51
column2: If reliable witnesses would have testified before a competent court in the presence of his wife to the same charges as those of A and B, Zeligman would have been justified in divorcing her. Although the evidence speaks of indecency and not of infidelity, and although the evidence is divided, the court would have recognized the charges as sufficient ground for a divorce even without the payment of the ketubah. The objection raised by Zeligman in his rebuttal against the testimony of the defense would then be sustained by this court. Under the circumstances, however, it is obligatory to reject Zeligman's plea for the following reasons.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).52
column2: First, if Zeligman were right in his rebuttal that the testimony against A and B ought to be annulled because it was given in their absence, then their own testimony ought to be annulled, because it was given in the absence of his wife. His declaration that no witness would have testified against her in her presence, and that no court would have convicted her under the same conditions because her father dominated the city, is known to be untrue. His own faction controlled the city of Prague at the time of the trial. Besides, he refused to appear before the court of Rabbis Sterenberg, Stengly, and Bern, who are known to be competent rabbis and who would try the case without fear or favor. Moreover, even if it were true that the city of Prague was intimidated by her father, she could not lose her right to defend herself before the law on that account.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).53
column2: Second, in cases of matrimonial relations, where the chastity of the woman is involved, her right to live with her husband, the right of her husband to divorce her, and her right to remarry another man, the witnesses must be treated with all the rigor and scrutiny of those in capital cases. Therefore, a) since two competent witnesses testified that A and B were informers, and many more witnesses established the fact that they were known publicly as suspects and worthless individuals, which disqualifies them to act in capital cases as witnesses, they could not for the same reason act as witnesses against Miriam. Although they were not legally disqualified, and their evidence might still be taken in civil cases, their testimony against Miriam is void. b) Since they failed to indicate in their testimony the time of the alleged clandestine meeting of Miriam and X, their testimony is void. c) Since the testimony of A and that of B indicate two different acts, each attested by one witness, their evidence is split. And as it is unlawful to convict a person in a capital case on split evidence, so Miriam cannot be similarly convicted. d) Since the similarity of the wording of their testimony raises suspicion as to its validity, they should have been cross-examined: and the court having failed to do so, their evidence is void. e) Since the judges of the court (if any court was held) before whom this evidence was given are unreliable, as they did not cross-examine the witnesses, and as their signatures are illegible (they cannot be allowed to validate them now) and nobody knows who they are, the evidence is void.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).54
column2: Third, a court is permitted to execute punishment on the basis of actual facts, though not ascertained by legal evidence. This court, therefore, is now taking the right, on the basis of all the evidence given here, to disqualify the witnesses A and B, although they are not present. And they shall from now on not be permitted to testify even in the presence of the accused, a) because they are publicly known as suspicious characters; b) because they did not honor the summons of the court even under the penalty of the herem.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).55
column2: The court rejects the rest of the testimony produced by Zeligman.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).56
column2: Exhibit No. I by Solomon ben Eliezer Zelkind does not imply any privacy between Miriam and X; it does not even prove indecency. a) Because he stated that he saw them in a public place.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).57
column2: Exhibit No. II by Solomon ben Eliezer Zelkind evinces no clandestine misconduct, either.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).58
column2: a) Because another man might have been with them in the room.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).59
column2: b) No woman can be charged of having been closeted with a man during the time her husband is in town.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).60
column2: c) Meeting a woman in privacy in the company of a man would not prohibit her from living with her husband, for if such were the rule no woman would be able to live with her husband.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).61
column2: Exhibit No. III by Solomon ben Eliezer Zelkind charges Miriam with indecency, but the charge is no ground for divorce.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).62
column2: a) He did not testify in person, and written evidence is not accepted in capital cases.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).63
column2: b) He acknowledged, before his testimony reached the court, that he wrote the testimony under duress in order to get back his pledges, which acknowledgment annulled his testimony.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).64
column2: Exhibit No. IV by the woman is no ground for divorce.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).65
column2: a) Because another man might have been with them in the house that night.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).66
column2: Exhibit No. V by the little boy is of no significance at all.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).67
column2: a) Because children are ruled to be unreliable in capital cases.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).68
column2: The persistent rumor about Miriam's misconduct would not prohibit Zeligman from living with her again. It is obvious that the rumor was spread by Zeligman himself, by his relatives, by the false witnesses that he solicited, and by Mordecai's enemies. His assertion that he believes in the witnesses and in the rumors, and that this, according to the law, prohibits him from living with his wife, again does not tally with the facts on hand. a) Were the witnesses of honest and reliable character, upon whose integrity Zeligman would rely in other affairs, his assertion that he believes them with regard to his wife would have to be sustained. But as a matter of fact Zeligman would not believe these suspects in anything else, therefore he cannot say that he believes their evidence against his wife. b) According to his own testimony he noticed nothing about his wife to warrant an accusation of infidelity. c) Two years ago he wanted to return to her and live with her again. d) Moreover, since that belief, according to his own statement, was based on the testimony of witnesses whose words the court has already annulled, he cannot any longer maintain that he is not permitted to live with his wife again.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).69
column2: Zeligman has the right to live with his wife again and cannot divorce her against her free will. He could even be forced to live with her if she wished.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).70
column2: However, since this opinion has no precedent in the law, no reunion shall take place unless approved by two scholars of two different cities, each of whom heads a rabbinical school there. If neither of the litigants attempts to obtain such approval within three months, Zeligman would then have the right to divorce his wife upon the payment of her ketubah and other money promised in her dowry. The bill of divorce, no matter how delivered, would then be no forced divorce.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).71
column2: Zeligman's statement that he has other witnesses to testify against his wife, but he does not know their whereabouts, holds the attention of the bet-din. The decision of the rabbis of Prague that any witness refusing to appear before this bet-din during this trial should not again be eligible to testify in the case, does not meet with the approval of the bet-din. If Zeligman has competent and reliable witnesses he may file a new charge at any time in the future against his wife.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).72
column2: But while the case, under present conditions, has been adjudged in favor of his wife, no single witness should appear before a bet-din to testify against her even in her presence; no witnesses should give evidence in her absence; and nobody should carry defamatory reports about her. Such acts will be regarded as slander and will be punished accordingly. If Zeligman himself will continue to disgrace her and injure her repuation he will be guilty of defaming and dishonoring the name of his own wife and will also be punished accordingly.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).73
column2: The "judges" who admitted the testimony in the absence of Miriam and then tried her in her absence deserve a severer punishment than merely invalidating their signatures. In other words, they ought to be treated more harshly than mere expulsion from the legal profession. But since they are not here and the bet-din cannot try them in their absence, therefore let their conscience be their own judge, and let their degradation be their recompense.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).74
Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).75
column2: The case was then referred to Luria. At the first instance he refused to review it, because he believed the Isserles court competent enough to decide it alone. But, being moved by the tears of Mordecai Katz and urged by the leaders of Lublin, he examined the case and made the following decision.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).76
column2: I. The main evidence speaks of indecency and not of infidelity. No testimony was given that they were found nude together, hence there is no charge of adultery, according to Rashi. Rashi and Rabbenu Gershon, Rif, Rambam, Rabbenu Hananeel, and Rabbenu Tam hold that only infidelity is ground for divorce.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).77
column2: Even according to Sheiltot, Rosh, and Rabbenu Meir, who hold that evidence of indecency in addition to a persistent evil rumor is ground for divorce, Zeligman has no claim to divorce his wife. The rumor must come from a different source and tell of different facts from those of the evidence. And this rumor was spread by the witnesses who testified to the indecency.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).78
column2: The testimony of the woman, of the child, and of Zelkind has no significance whatsoever. Even Zelkind's exhibit III is no ground for divorce. It does not speak of a clandestine meeting at all, because there are always pedestrians in the streets of Prague, the guards are going their rounds, and the students who go home at night watch the houses and knock at the open doors.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).79
column2: II. The evidence was given in the absence of the accused, and therefore it is invalid under any circumstances. Zeligman's plea, even if it were true, that he was forced to give the evidence in the absence of his wife, because his father-in-law controlled the city and undue influence would have been exerted upon the court, cannot be sustained. Moreover, it is true that Mordecai Katz predominated over the city at one time in the past, but not at the time of the trial. When the trial took place Zeligman's faction was administering the affairs of the community, and Mordecai was humble and submissive. One of Zeligman's witnesses even inflicted a number of blows on Mordecai in the presence of the leaders of the city; and when he was arrested, he was kept under guard for a period of four weeks without being convicted. Furthermore, Miriam could not have been denied the right to defend herself on account of her father.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).80
column2: Zeligman's argument that the evidence affects him as much as his wife, for it prohibits him from living with her just as it prohibits her from living with him, and that since he was present at the trial the evidence should be ruled valid although she was absent, is based on no foundation. The court is not concerned in saving him for his wife or vice versa. The court is only anxious to save the good name of his wife, while his name, on the other hand, was not stigmatized by the evidence.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).81
column2: Again, the congregation of Prague has a special ordinance not to give any testimony except in the presence of the leaders of the city, the two sextons, and the public scribe. The evidence, having been presented in violation of this ordinance, is void.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).82
column2: III. Testimony must be given before three men who are experts in the laws of evidence. The bet-din before whom the evidence was given was not well versed in the laws of evidence. It failed to cross-examine the witnesses, as legally required. And according to the rulings of Rabbenu Tam and Rashba no sanction for a divorce can be granted without first cross-examining the witnesses. Hence Zeligman has no right to divorce his wife.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).83
column2: IV. The lack of moral integrity of the witnesses disqualifies them from testifying in any case. They were not qualified to testify in this case, in particular, because they were proven to be Mordecai's life enemies. It was further proven that Zeligman and his relatives were soliciting false witnesses. The evidence was delivered in writing, which is accepted rabbinically in money matters only, but not in ritual cases, and especially in this case, which must be treated with the same strictness as capital cases.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).84
column2: V. In general, Zeligman conducted the entire case in a fraudulent manner. His assertion that he is not allowed to live with his wife because he believes his witnesses, is not true. He acknowledged that he himself did not see anything indecent about her, and certainly he would not believe the false witnesses whom he himself hired.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).85
column2: Since men cannot divorce their wives nowadays against their free will, nor have they the right to marry more than one wife because of the herem of Rabbenu Gershon, therefore they who are in love with other women turn to such deceptive practices as Zeligman did to rid themselves of their wives.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).86
column2: Zeligman is allowed to live with his wife.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Infidelity(xxxiii).87
column2: The decision should be proclaimed in every synagogue.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).1
column2: Nathan, son of Israel Lieberman, promised his daughter Dinah in marriage to Samuel ben Baruk of Cracow, whom the matrimonial agents introduced as one possessing the finest qualities, both as to integrity and general ability, but who in reality was a gambler and a drunkard. When the father of the bride learned of this, he went to Cracow to break the engagement. The friends and relatives of the bridegroom, however, threatened that they would put him under a ban and that they would collect from him the fine prescribed for breaking the marriage contract. Not being able to combat them, he lent his ear to the more peaceful friends of the bridegroom, who told him that the groom was still young and would reform under the influence of a good wife. Under the circumstances he called the bridegroom and exacted an oath that he would no longer gamble or drink to excess.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).2
column2: Two weeks after his marriage the husband relapsed into his bad habits and began to visit gentile drinking places, drink ritually forbidden wine, and come home drunk. This disgusted his wife so much that she refused to live with him. He had become altogether repugnant to her, and she wished to be divorced from him.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).3
column2: Q. a) Is repugnance sufficient ground to force her husband to give her a bill of divorce?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).4
column2: b) Could he be forced to divorce her because he did not keep his promise given under oath to live a virtuous life?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).5
column2: c) If not, could she be compelled to live with him under the circumstances?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).6
column2: A. a) The husband cannot be compelled to grant her a bill of divorce on the ground of repugnance caused by his drunkenness and visiting gentile saloons. Were he even to become a convert, he could not be forced to divorce her. A husband could be coerced to grant his wife a bill of divorce only were he to strike her, maltreat her, or become afflicted with an offensive odor, but not for mental cruelty.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).7
column2: b) Not fulfilling his special promise under the oath to live an upright life is no ground for divorce either.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Is Plea of Repugnancy Ground For Divorce(lxix).8
column2: c) However, she cannot, under the circumstances, be compelled to live with him. Her dowry and other belongings which she brought from her father's home should remain hers. If any of the things mentioned in her ketubah were lost, the husband is to be held responsible. The money of the dowry meanwhile is to be put in a trust, the interest of which shall be collected by her. And if they do not come to an understanding at the end of one year, the trust should be turned over to her.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Money Deposited Under Duress(xxiv V).1
column2: A man named Hillel of Lublin, failing after several years in his endeavor to marry the widow Idil, circulated a report that he had betrothed her in the absence of witnesses. The widow strenuously denied the rumor. He then started to molest her, causing her trouble in her business, whereby she suffered great damage.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Money Deposited Under Duress(xxiv V).2
column2: To get rid of his importunities she agreed to accept a divorce from him, which he was willing to grant on condition that she give him a certain amount of money. But before she deposited the promised sum with the trustee, to be delivered to Hillel upon receipt of her divorce, she protested in the presence of two witnesses that the whole affair was nothing but a device to extort money from her. Then, when he gave her the bill of divorce, she did not permit the trustee to hand the money over until the case was decided by a Jewish court. The case was then brought before the court of Joseph Kohen; but before its decision was pronounced, friends of the widow, who wanted to know Luria's opinion in the matter, sent him the case in Ostrog. This occurred in the year 1551.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Money Deposited Under Duress(xxiv V).3
column2: Q. Is the protest of the widow to be rejected or sustained?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Money Deposited Under Duress(xxiv V).4
column2: A. Although I have not heard the claim of the other party and it is not proper for a judge to respond to a question or to pass an opinion in money matters before hearing the claims of both litigants, and especially in a case which is under the advisement of a competent court, yet since widows and orphans are entitled to special consideration I shall advise the court, not in the capacity of judge, but as a mere friend of the widow, to find the verdict in her favor. Even if the court has already heard the claims of the other party, it still has the right to accept my opinion if it finds it acceptable.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Money Deposited Under Duress(xxiv V).5
column2: First, however, I shall decide whether she has the right to remarry, although I was not asked to give my opinion on this point, because that question is more important than the monetary matter.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Money Deposited Under Duress(xxiv V).6
column2: The widow, according to the law, is allowed to marry even a Kohen, although she did not fulfill the condition upon which the bill of divorce was granted to her; because the divorce, under the circumstances, has no more effect upon the widow than a divorce upon an unmarried woman. But taking into consideration that the people regard her as a divorced woman, because the bill was written by a competent rabbi who would not have written it without substantial ground, she should not marry a Kohen, in order to avoid evil talk. However, she is allowed to marry an Israelite even if the report of Hillel that he betrothed her was true, because he cannot annul the bill of divorce on her failure to fulfill the condition of paying him the money. All conditions made in connection with a bill of divorce are annulled by the court prior to the writing of the bill.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Money Deposited Under Duress(xxiv V).7
column2: Her protest, concerning the money placed with the trustee, should be sustained. And if the knavery of the man was known to the trustee he may return the money to her even without the order of the court. His reputation as trustee will not suffer by it, for he too is obliged to give aid against violence. But if he did not know the circumstances under which the woman deposited the money with him, he should wait for the order of the court to return the money to her.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).1
column2: Luria quoted from his comprehensive work "Yam Shel Shelomoh" concerning the procedure of halizah:

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).2
column2: There must be five judges to perform the halizah ceremony; three of them must be ordained rabbis and the other two may be laymen. They must not be related to one another nor to the parties concerned. A man who is blind in one eye cannot act as judge among the three ordained, but he may be one of the other two.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).3
column2: The ceremony of halizah must be enacted in a public place; a synagogue is preferable. The place must be reserved a day before the ceremony by the five judges who will act at the halizah. The chief judge must then declare the place legal for the occasion by saying: Here is the place where the halizah will be performed tomorrow. Then he must rehearse with the others the order in which they are to sit at the ceremony.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).4
column2: The ceremony of halizah must take place between the afternoon prayer and the evening prayer.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).5
column2: On the day of the halizah the chief judge should sit at one end of the room and the other two ordained judges should sit near him, one to the right and the other to the left. The other judges should be seated on a separate bench nearby. The audience remains standing at the other end of the room.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).6
column2: A small bench should be placed for the yabam and the widow. Her face must be covered with a veil, and she should not spit until told by the judges.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).7
column2: On being questioned by the presiding judge they must stand up. The question whether they would like to marry each other must be answered in the negative. They must assert that their refusal to marry comes of their free will. Should they have vowed not to marry one another the vow must be dissolved. Upon questioning the widow whether or not she has been fasting that day, she must answer that she did not fast.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).8
column2: The yabam must not be younger than thirteen years and one day, and the widow not younger than twelve years and one day. The ceremony cannot take place before three months after the death of her husband.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).9
column2: A shoe for the right foot made from the leather of a clean animal is then given to the yabam and he raises it in order to gain possession thereof. The sexton then washes the right foot of the yabam and puts the shoe on his foot and ties it. The yabam then stands up against the wall and the chief judge teaches him to say: Lo hafazti (I do not desire to marry her:—Deuteronomy, 25-8), and the widow he teaches to say: Lo abah (He will not perform the duty of a husband's brother unto me:—ib., 25-7), and then he should read with her: Maen yebami le-hakim le-ahiw shem be-lsrael (My husband's brother refuseth to raise up unto his brother a name in Israel:—ib.). The widow then lowers herself to the floor and unties the lace and removes the shoe, from his foot with her right hand. If she lacks one arm she may use her teeth to untie the shoe. She dashes the shoe on the floor and the judge tells her to spit on the floor in front of the yabam.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).10
column2: The judge then reads: "So should it be done to the man that doth not build up his brother's house. And his name shall be called in Israel: The house of him who had his shoe loosed." The phrase "who had his shoe loosed" is repeated three times by all three judges. The ceremony is then finished with a benediction by the presiding judge: Baruk Hu asher kideshanu be-mizwotaw we-hukaw shel Abraham abinu, omitting Adonai Elohenu melek ha-olam.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Procedure of Halizah(xc).11
column2: He then tells her that she is allowed to marry and hands her a bill of halizah. In Poland no such document is given her.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Religion in Married Life(xli).1
column2: Disagreement between husband and wife reached such an acute stage that the wife, encouraged by her father, demanded a divorce of her husband. She complained that he had made his religion an object of derision. The local court sent the question to Luria:

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Religion in Married Life(xli).2
column2: Q. May the husband be coerced to grant his wife a divorce on the ground that he is treating religion with scorn?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Religion in Married Life(xli).3
column2: A. The husband cannot be forced to give his wife a bill of divorce on the charge that he regards religion as a frivolous affair. Moreover, even if the charge were true, or he was converted to another religion, but still cared for his wife as the law requires of a Jewish husband, she could not compel him to give her a divorce.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Religion in Married Life(xli).4
column2: But she cannot be compelled to live with him, either. She may take her wedding outfit given to her by her father and return home. The husband, then, would no longer be responsible for its depreciation. And she has no right to take with her the wardrobe which her husband gave her.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Religion in Married Life(xli).5
column2: The court, however, should find out from her parents, under the threat of a herem, whether or not they advised her to make this accusation against her husband because she was in love with another man. In case such a deceit be discovered she should lose all the dowry brought to her husband on her marriage. And if any violence be used to force the husband to grant her a divorce, she should be treated as a woman who refused her marital obligations and lose the right of collecting her ketubah.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Rumor of Marriage(cii).1
column2: In 1572 a rumor was spread in the city of Byzantium that Jehiel b. Mosheh Meir ha-Kohen had betrothed Rachel, daughter of Hayyim. The girl's father sought the assistance of the bet-din to suppress the rumor. Witnesses and the alleged bridegroom testified before the court of Eliakim ben Mordecai, Israel ben Samuel, and Aaron ben Moses, that the rumor had no ground. A transcript of the evidence, signed by the witnesses and the court and approved by Naphtali ben Menahem, was given to the girl. When the rumor persisted, another bet-din of Isaac ben Aaron David Frank (cantor of Byzantium), Abraham ben Baruk, and Perez ben Solomon ha-Levi Luria issued a general summons, that whosoever knew aught of this betrothal should come and report to them. As nobody appeared, the bet-din sent the sexton from house to house to question the inhabitants. But nobody knew anything about it. This tribunal again gave the girl an official document to the effect that she had never been betrothed. As the second bet-din could not halt the rumor either, Hayyim turned to Luria and asked:

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Rumor of Marriage(cii).2
column2: Q. Can such a rumor prohibit his daughter from marrying?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Rumor of Marriage(cii).3
column2: A. A rumor originated by one witness should be utterly disregarded and suppressed. In this case all witnesses traced the rumor to the same man. Moreover, I have learned that this man was looking for revenge. He spread the rumor against Rachel, in all likelihood, because her father had informed the government concerning a certain man. I therefore prohibit the spreading of the rumor, and allow the girl to marry even the high priest.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Treatment After Childbirth(xlv).1
column2: Q. Can a husband be compelled to supply his wife during her confinement period, usually extending over three or four weeks, with better nourishment, and with such other considerations as hiring a nurse for her or a servant for the house?

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Treatment After Childbirth(xlv).2
column2: A. Women during their confinement period nowadays are in the same category as sick women, and they must be treated as such. This is not in harmony with the expressed talmudic law, but laws are changed according to time and place. As the husband's obligation to clothe his wife varies with time and place according to the Talmud, so should his obligations with regard to food. The husband, therefore, can be forced to treat his wife during her confinement with the special consideration prevailing among the average family.

column1: Meir, Ii Matrimonial Cases and Domestic Relations, Treatment After Childbirth(xlv).3
Meir, Iii Slander, Aspersion of Ancestry(xii).1
column2: A slanderous rumor was circulated about their mother's family, to the injury of the reputation of Bezalel's sons, Hayyim, Leib, Sinai, and Simon, who were about to be ordained as rabbis. A number of prominent men were disturbed by this rumor and they asked Luria:

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Aspersion of Ancestry(xii).2
column2: Q. Is there any ground to this rumor?

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Aspersion of Ancestry(xii).3
column2: A. My grandfather, Isaac Klauberia, who was a relative of and well acquainted with the family in question, respected it greatly and never told me anything disreputable concerning it. Therefore, I regard this rumor vicious, and am prepared to put a ban on anyone who will continue to circulate it.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Defamation of Ancestry(ci).1
column2: In 1572, during a heated argument at a game of chance, Eliakum ben Samuel of Belz, Poland, called his adversary X "nadler", an opprobious epithet reflecting upon the legitimacy of many families.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Defamation of Ancestry(ci).2
column2: In the presence of both litigants, Naphtali ben Mattithiah, Judah ben Saul, and Samuel ben Mordecai testified before a court of laymen, Jeruham ben Joseph, Isaac ben Mordecai, and Moses ben Samuel, that they had heard the slanderous tale uttered by Eliakum, and that this was done with the intention of injuring the reputation of X. The court sent a transcript of the testimony, accompanied by two witnesses, Isaac ben Moses and David ben Moses Mordecai, to Isaac of Belz, who validated it; and then it was sent to Rabbi Solomon of Chelem for his opinion. Rabbi Solomon, in turn, sent the case to Luria asking:

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Defamation of Ancestry(ci).3
column2: Q. What kind of punishment should be inflicted upon the calumniator?

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Defamation of Ancestry(ci).4
column2: A. This traducer, who used the reproachful name of "nadler", attaching disgrace to the whole lineage of X, should be lashed in the synagogue, unless he redeem himself by giving said X thirty-nine zehubim, and asking for forgiveness from God and then from X. He should withdraw the insolent appellation in public, and after seven days repair to the cemetery of Lemberg, where X's parents are resting in peace, accompanied by a quorum of ten distinguished men, including the cantor and the sexton, walk, from the entrance of the cemetery to the graves of the deceased, barefooted, and again ask for forgiveness from God and from the dead.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Malice(xxviii).1
column2: Someone spread a malicious rumor about a certain man, that he had slept with his own married sister in one bed and bathed with her in one bathtub.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Malice(xxviii).2
column2: This terrible accusation was brought to the notice of Rabbi Meir of Padua, Italy, who in turn consulted the opinion of Moses Isserles, and expressed his wish that the latter obtain Luria's opinion in the matter. Isserles then sent the case to Luria and asked him:

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Malice(xxviii).3
column2: Q. What punishment ought to be inflicted upon this malicious slanderer?

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Malice(xxviii).4
column2: A. According to talmudic law, he would deserve the corporal punishment of the "forty lashes" four times over, twice for accusing the man of incest with a woman that is his sister and married, and twice again for accusing the woman of incest and adultery, which should be inflicted in the synagogue after the minhah services on Mondays and Thursdays during two consecutive weeks. But since we are now unable to enforce the law of the forty lashes because of the fear of informers— the forty lashes now practiced is nothing more than a ceremony—therefore I would suggest, first, that a fine of eight gold Rhinish should be substituted for the lashes, plus court expenses. Second, that he should come to the synagogue during the services clothed in black, and confess his guilt while holding two black lighted candles in his hands, and ask for forgiveness from God and from the people in question; the hazan of the congregation should at the same time announce that this slanderer begs for pardon.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Malice(xxviii).5
column2: Should the slanderer not submit to this punishment, he should be put under a ban.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Scurrilous Language(lix).1
column2: Evidence was taken against a man of Novogrodek (Russia: Province of Minsk), that he said to a woman who had refused to dance with him: "I know why you refuse me; it is because I do not want to pay you three guldens. You act likewise, I was told, towards your own husband; you would not let him come near you unless he paid you three guldens."

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Scurrilous Language(lix).2
column2: Q. What punishment should be meted out for such vile language?

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Scurrilous Language(lix).3
column2: A. Were it even true that the woman in question said that she would not take the ritual bath before her husband gave her three guldens as the defendant attempts to prove, he should escape no punishment, because such talk by a woman should be taken with a grain of salt. It is a psychological fact that women seek to exalt themselves when they are prating and babbling among their own sex, and their greatest satisfaction is to speak of their husbands and of their commanding influence over them. But no significance should be given to such gossip.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Scurrilous Language(lix).4
column2: Therefore, the congregation should compel the man to stand before the ark in the synagogue with lighted candles in his hands and beg of God, of the woman, and of her husband to be pardoned for his scurrility; then he should be ordered to sit at the door outside the synagogue for four weeks as a mourner. And he must pay all the expenses incurred by the husband in connection with this trial. In case the delinquent refuses to comply with this decision, he should be excommunicated.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Scurrilous Language(lix).5
column2: The hazan of the congregation should read this decision in the synagogue before the members of the community.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).1
column2: A husband brought an accusation of immorality against his wife before Chief Rabbi Abraham and his court of justice. The court ordered both parties not to appeal the case to any other court, in order to avoid any further altercations between the families, to which both parties consented.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).2
column2: The wife's father, however, procured witnesses of a suspicious character, and in the absence of his son-in-law brought counter-charges before the court of a local rabbi to discredit and dishonor his son-in-law and his entire family. He accused the father, Simon Gunsberg, of having lived with the mother before marriage, and since unmarried girls were not enjoined by law to take the ritual bath, the son was conceived by an "unclean" woman and was therefore a bastard. He furthermore caused them great harm by informing the government against them. He even sought to avenge himself upon Rabbi Abraham, before whom his son-in-law had brought the accusations against his daughter, by informing the government against him.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).3
column2: Mendel, the district rabbi, then asked Luria:—

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).4
column2: Q. 1) Is the decision of the local rabbi to be considered?

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).5
column2: 2) What punishment should be meted out to the informer?

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).6
column2: A. 1) No, the decision of the local rabbi cannot be honored.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).7
column2: a) A Jewish court is not permitted to receive statements of witnesses in the absence of the accused, especially in a case like this, which concerns the virtue and uprightness of a family, unless the accused deliberately failed to appear before the court when summoned.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).8
column2: b) Both parties were prohibited by the first court of justice from making further appeals.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).9
column2: c) The witnesses were found to be perjured.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).10
column2: 2) I would have allowed the husband's family to take the life of the informer, if need be, to save themselves. But, in my opinion, the wife's father was merely acting to save the honor of his daughter and not with the intention of causing any damage to his son-in-law and his family. Therefore, he could not be regarded as an informer in the strict sense of the word, and should not be dealt with as such. But he must pay for all the damages he has done. He should save the honor of Rabbi Abraham at any price, even if this cost him his entire fortune, and humbly apologize to the rabbi for disgracing him in the eyes of the city officials, and definitely accept his decision.

column1: Meir, Iii Slander, Witnesses and Informers(xi).11
Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, A Girl of Unknown Paternity(xvii).1
column2: Q. Is a female of an unknown father allowed to be married to a kohen?6

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, A Girl of Unknown Paternity(xvii).2
column2: A. If upon investigation, the mother affirmed that she had cohabited with a Jew, she and the daughter are allowed to marry priests, even in cities where Jews form a minority. In cities were Jews form a majority, she and the daughter are allowed to marry priests even when it is not known with whom she cohabited. But in cities where the gentiles form the majority, and no investigation has been made with regard to the identity of the father, neither the mother nor the daughter should be allowed to marry priests. Should either of them already be married to a kohen, however, she need not be divorced.

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Catamenial Period(lxxxii).1
column2: Q. If the menses began after the night prayer, while it was yet broad daylight, may that day be reckoned as one of the five menstrual days, after which the women are allowed to change their underwear, or does the counting begin with the next day? In other words, is the reciting of the night prayer a determining factor in establishing the end of the day?

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Catamenial Period(lxxxii).2
column2: A. In places where the women count five days for their menstrual period they may change their underwear on the fifth day, even if the menses began after the night prayer. And in places where they count only four days and the woman herself has said the night prayer with the congregation, she should follow the stricter practice and start counting the four days from the next day; but if she has not said the night prayer, she may count the remainder of that day as one of the four days.

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Catamenial Period(lxxxii).3
Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).1
column2: In the city of Padua, Italy, the ritual bath house of the Jewish community was placed in the yard of the synagogue, and the women going there before dark were exposed to the view and comments of the loiterers. For it was not customary for women to go to the synagogue for evening prayers. The more discreet women would postpone their obligatory immersions until Saturday night. Judah, and then his son Abraham Minz, ordered that the women go to cleanse and wash their hair preparatory to immersion by night rather than at twilight. This was based on a precedent. In the early part of the thirteenth century Eleazar ben Judah of Worms established a custom that, for the sake of chastity, women should conceal their immersion from their neighbors.

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).2
column2: Meir of Padua and his son Judah, as each held the rabbinic post in Padua, upheld this reform by declaring it permissible for the women to take the ritual bath at night. Contrary to all the facts mentioned, another rabbi of Padua, in the absence of Judah, delivered a lecture before the women in which he opposed this and warned them that night cleansing would not render them ritually clean to cohabit with their husbands, so that the children of a cohabitation after such a cleansing would be bastards.

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).3
column2: This controversy reached Moses Isserles, who on Judah's request sent it to Luria for adjudication.

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).4
column2: Q. 1. Is there any ground for Rabbi Meir of Padua and his son Judah upholding this custom?

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).5
column2: 2. Would the children born of a cohabitation which took place after such night cleansing be bastards?

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).6
column2: A. 1. This custom was properly upheld. The custom of going to the bath house by day rather than at night was instituted by, the women themselves, in order that they be able to do their cleansing and the washing of their hair more properly (the bath houses were poorly illuminated at night). But now, since it is detrimental for them to go there by day, the custom of going at night is preferable.

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).7
column2: 2. The statement of the rabbi that children of such cohabitation would be bastards was certainly made by error. For, according to the law the child of a nidah is not a bastard, although it holds an inferior position in Israel.

column1: Meir, Iv Ritual Purification, Night Cleansing of a Nidah(vi).8
column2: I would advise the rabbi that he retract his words and acknowledge his mistake in the very place where he delivered his first lecture, and apologize to Judah for opposing in his absence a custom which his father and other rabbis, before his father, had instituted.

column1: Meir, Ix Sukkot, Ostrog's Lulab(viii).1
column2: In 1553 the congregation of Ostrog had forgotten to buy an ethrog for Sukkot. Some people of the congregation, however, became aware of the fact shortly before Sukkot and they sent a messenger to the next city to procure one. The messenger returned Friday two hours before sundown with the ethrog and palm, but without the necessary myrtle, and Saturday was the first day of Sukkot. The congregation was about to send a gentile to the neighboring Jewish community to obtain myrtle, though it be of last year, in order to be able to carry out the ceremony of handling the lulab at the Sunday morning services.

column1: Meir, Ix Sukkot, Ostrog's Lulab(viii).2
column2: Luria, however, would not allow them to send the gentile because of the rule of shebut. In this case, he said, the rule of shebut could not be put off in favor of the ordinance to perform the ceremony of the festive wreath. For the ceremony of the festive wreath on the second day of Sukkot in any place, even in the territory of Palestine excepting Jerusalem, is only a rabbinic ordinance.

column1: Meir, Ix Sukkot, Ostrog's Lulab(viii).3
column2: Sunday morning, the second day of Sukkot, Luria ordered the cantor to wave the lulab at the proper time of the services, in order that the law of lulab be remembered by the people of the congregation, but without saying the necessary benediction. Sunday night, the third night of Sukkot, he sent a messenger for the myrtle, and on the following morning told the congregation to say the benediction shehehianu, since shehehianu is said even in connection with precepts not mentioned in the five books of Moses, such as the lighting of the Hanukah candles, and the reading of Esther on Purim.

column1: Meir, Ix Sukkot, Shemini Azereth Eve(lxviii).1
column2: Q. Is it customary to wait for kiddush and the evening meal on Shemini-Azereth eve until it is quite dark?

column1: Meir, Ix Sukkot, Shemini Azereth Eve(lxviii).2
column2: A. I never heard of such a custom; yet it would be proper to do so in order to avoid making the benediction lesheb ba-sukkah.

column1: Meir, Ix Sukkot, Waving the Palm Branch(lxxxiii).1
column2: Q. What is the correct way of waving the lulab?

column1: Meir, Ix Sukkot, Waving the Palm Branch(lxxxiii).2
column2: A. There is a good deal of discussion among rabbinic authorities with regard to this question. But the proper way is to wave the lulab thrice up and down and thrice to and fro, making three motions at the first to-and-fro waving. He who waves the lulab otherwise is to be considered an ignoramus.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Abraham Ibn Ezra.1
column2: In appraising a work affecting the law Luria invariably applied the Talmud as sole criterion of its excellence. Hence, it is not surprising that Luria did not admit Abraham ibn Ezra into the category of rabbinic scholars. The high esteem in which he was held as poet and religious philosopher did not shield him from Luria's judgment. Of Abraham ibn Ezra Luria declared without moderation:

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Abraham Ibn Ezra.2
column2: "He was no talmudist; the major portion of his work, including his commentary (on the Bible) treats of astronomy, natural sciences, and other secular subjects. Yet he dared to contradict biblical scholars and the Talmud. Out of ignorance he ascribed biblical laws to the Talmud and rabbinic laws to the Bible. He countenanced the forbidden and prohibited sanctioned practices. His exegesis is not followed in matters of law, for in his legal pronouncements he often overruled the decisions of both tannaim and amoraim. He boasted that his independent rational faculty would alone guide him in interpreting the Bible and that he would not accept the commentaries of others. His work may best be judged by his adherents—heretics and Sadducees."<xref rid="fn50">50</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Authority of Rabbinic Tribunal.1
column2: Luria reviled the rabbis as individuals. He did not, however, intend thereby to diminish their jurisdiction. In fact, he resisted every attempt to impair the authority inherent in the rabbinic tribunal.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Authority of Rabbinic Tribunal.2
column2: Owing to the prevailing ignorance among rabbis, Joseph Colon, foremost talmudist of Italy in the fifteenth century, stripped them of the power of deciding cases wherein conflict of authority existed among the halakists. He held, for example, that where Rashi and Rabbenu Tam were not in accord on the law, the rabbi was powerless to resolve the conflict; and ruled, further, that the parties to the litigation had to be left in status quo.<xref rid="fn78">78</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Authority of Rabbinic Tribunal.3
column2: Luria refused thus to limit the scope of the court. He said: "It is definitely beyond the province of the rabbis to adjudicate controversies in which the question involved has been sealed with the talmudic teku (let it stand). For on such questions the Talmud ventured no opinion. However, in the event the rabbi is confronted with a conflict of authority which resulted in a declared sefeka, a talmudic draw, leaving the law in doubt and unsettled, it is mandatory upon him to elect and adopt one of the varying views, in order to conclude the litigation before him; and, with greater reason is the rabbi obligated to reach a determination which necessitates a choice between the conflicting opinions of post-talmudic authorities. For in such cases it is the plain duty of the rabbi to explore and review the sources of the law with the view toward clearing the indicated doubt. The incompetence of the rabbi can not prescribe or curtail the function of the rabbinic court. 'Jeftah be-doro ke-Samuel be-doro'79—i.e., the incumbent neither transcends nor submerges the office. In the event the decision is withheld in such a mandatory case the claimant may rely upon the authority which favors him and, in self-help, seize and legally retain the disputed chattel."80

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Benjamin Zeeb.1
column2: Luria showed by undisputed proof that Rabbi Benjamin ben Mattithaia's work Benjamin Zeeb was laden with plagiarism, misquotations, and misinterpretations, and cautioned against reliance thereon in matters of law.66

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, How Luria Viewed the Situation.1
column2: Luria had to contend with a long and distinguished list of codifiers, exegetes, and innovators, whom he held responsible for the deplorable status of the Talmud as he perceived it. Their fame and prestige did not save them from the withering criticism of which Luria was capable. He fought them fearlessly, sparing neither the rishonim nor the aharonim.24

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, How Luria Viewed the Situation.2
column2: The various codifiers, geonim included,<xref rid="fn25">25</xref> sought to bring into definite relief the opinions of the Talmud. They had hoped to eliminate the obscurities resulting chiefly from methods of presentation. They did not succeed; their plans were well conceived but poorly executed. The codes still abounded in ambiguities, burdened with equivocations of their own creation. Moreover, the rabbis of the later period, in promulgating new laws on their own authority, added to the chaos. The laws, besides failing to be expressly predicated on the talmudic text, were at times at direct variance with talmudic precepts. In any event the prohibition of the final editors of the Talmud against adding to or deducting from the work was openly flouted and ignored. The ultimate authority was weakened; confusion and perplexity resulted. Schools of law sprang up in different countries, each apparently vested with the power of formulating its own code, binding upon its adherents. Estrangement was created between Jews subject to different codes.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, How Luria Viewed the Situation.3
column2: Luria witnessed the resurgence of an old controversy in the development of rabbinic law. The leading schools of Shammai and Hillel, during the second century C.E., differed on pivotal questions. Conflicting legal precedents were established by other contemporary schools of law. Confusion and hostility were the consequences. Rabbi Judah ha-Nasi, at the close of the second century C.E., in his final written26 compilation and edition of the Mishnah, reconciled the divergent views of the tannaim and thus effected a consistent and accepted statement of law and tradition. The uniformity of doctrine thus laboriously achieved did not, however, preclude the controversies of the amoraim. Rabina and Rab Ashi, in the second half of the fifth century C. E., were accordingly impelled to assemble, arrange, and authoritatively restate in writing27 the vast disorganized mass of new laws. The Gemara was designed to reintroduce harmony and certainty. This aim was frustrated by the later tosafists and halakists, whose codices and expressed views were replete with inconsistencies and errors.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, How Luria Viewed the Situation.4
column2: To these were added the errata of the scribes, multiplied and perpetuated by the newly invented printing press. Inaccurate texts were cited by the rabbis and relied upon by the laity.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, How Luria Viewed the Situation.5
column2: The corruption of the professional rabbis was exceeded only by the ignorance of the congregations. Diversity of doctrine and confusion in the law were inevitable. Equilibrium in Jewish life was dangerously upset.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, How Luria Viewed the Situation.6
column2: Luria was vexed and alarmed by this condition. He regarded it as sorely aggravated by that strange triad, the sophistry of the pilpulists, distortion by the kabalists, and the alien influence of Greek philosophy.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Jacob Ben Asher.1
column2: In his introduction to the Turim, Jacob ben Asher affirmed that a quotation from his father (Rosh) must be deemed final and absolute. Luria warns against blind acceptance of this dictum, and adds this devastating comment: "The fact that he (Baal ha-Turim) agrees with his father does not pledge us to agree with him. In fact, established usages are often contrary to the opinions of the Turim.65

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Joseph Caro.1
column2: Luria finds imperfection also in the works of Joseph Caro. He discovered that in his monumental work, Bet Joseph on the Turim, Caro made unreasonable compromises with the law, and frequently decided against tradition, against the tosafists, and against the halakists. The Bet Joseph is not only a comprehensive commentary upon the Turim but an elaborate compilation of innovations from rare responsa, novellae, and other works, to which previous scholars did not have access. Luria points to this fact and to the magnitude of Caro's undertaking as well as to the dearth of accurate source books, in extenuation of the defects which marred the perfection of the Bet Joseph. Luria severely criticized Caro for the rule he adopted in rendering decisions. Caro held that in the event of a conflict of law, that statement of law governed which met the concurrence of any two of the three halakists, Rif, Rosh, and Rambam (Maimonides), the explicit opinions of other distinguished halakists to the contrary notwithstanding. For these reasons Luria withholds his unqualified sanction from the Bet Joseph.67

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Kabala.1
column2: Kabala, though like Grecian metaphysics it deals with supernatural phenomena, did, however, enlist Luria's enthusiasm. He was fascinated by the endeavor of kabala to bring the Scriptures and universal reason into harmony. But he deplored its essays into the domain of theurgy.<xref rid="fn98">98</xref>.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Kabala.2
column2: He often quotes kabalistic dicta with approval and himself employs kabalistic formulae. Nevertheless, he does not approve the dissemination of its esoteric doctrines among the populace. To Mordecai ben Tanhum he writes: "These upstarts pretend to fathom the Zohar. They glibly assert that they have penetrated the secret depths of the Torah. Would they understood the revealed surface of the Torah." Luria felt that the study of kabala should be confined to a select circle of inspired scholars.<xref rid="fn99">99</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria As Judge.1
column2: In the capacity of judge he manifested a genuinely democratic spirit and a touching humility. He kept abreast of the material and spiritual needs of the masses.<xref rid="fn100">100</xref> He was accordingly inclined toward tolerance and clemency; his rulings are distinguished for their leniency.<xref rid="fn101">101</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria As Judge.2
column2: He perceived that the exigencies of life entailed changes in customs and carried this perception to its logical conclusion—that an altered custom necessitates a modification of the law.<xref rid="fn102">102</xref> He did not refrain, therefore, from holding that a universal custom established by seafaring men in their marital relations can annul a talmudic precept, even one based on a biblical verse.<xref rid="fn103">103</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria and His Generation.1
column2: In the age of decadence in which he lived, Luria pitted himself against the deteriorating influences which beset Jewish life. With profound scholarship, rare acumen, and a fearless independence in thought and deed, he dedicated himself to the service of the law. For to Luria, the law was the bulwark of Jewish life.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Attitude Towards Predecessors and Contemporaries.1
column2: Luria was constantly confronted with conflicting precedents drawn from the prolific codices and digests. It will be profitable, therefore, to ascertain the comparative weight which Luria attached to the sources of the law. His judicial process in reaching a decision will thus be revealed.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Attitude Towards Predecessors and Contemporaries.2
column2: Luria, of course, did not question the authority of the Talmud. Its laws were not open to dispute. They were sanctioned by tradition, which he regarded as supreme.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Attitude Towards Predecessors and Contemporaries.3
column2: His attitude towards the Talmud is illustrated by an extraordinary utterance which he quotes: "The Written Law is brief and basic. The talmudic sages elucidated and elaborated the Written Law and thus formulated the Oral Law. The Oral Law merits the measure of sanction accorded the Written Law. It is the view of the rabbis that the Written and the Oral Law are derived from a common source; the origin of each is divine. The kabalists (traditionalists) maintain that posterity stood inchoate at the foot of Mount Sinai as God transmitted the Law, both Written and Oral." And to this quotation Luria adds: "The Written Law is a revelation, disclosed by word of mouth; the Oral Law is a revelation, lodged in the recesses of the mind. It is the revelation and not the medium of revelation which endows the Law with sanctity."<xref rid="fn30">30</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Enemies.1
column2: So critical an attitude gained few friends for Luria. His enemies were many. He was harassed to such an extent that he was compelled to resign his post at Brest-Litovsk. Then followed troublesome years of travel throughout Lithuania.<xref rid="fn86">86</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Enemies.2
column2: About 1550 he received an appointment as rabbi and head of the yeshibah at Ostrog,<xref rid="fn87">87</xref> where he was afterward named by the government district rabbi of Wolhynia.<xref rid="fn88">88</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Enemies.3
column2: Ostrog was noted as a seat of learning before Luria's arrival.<xref rid="fn89">89</xref> Its fame soon spread far and wide and students flocked to study at the yeshibah. But Luria had an unerring facility for arousing hostility. Enemies were quick to treat him harshly. His life at Ostrog was embittered. Even the students began to desert him. Luria again resigned his post.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Enemies.4
column2: In 1555 Luria was designated rabbi and head of the celebrated yeshibah at Lublin, Poland.<xref rid="fn90">90</xref> Here he encountered his most virulent adversary, Rabbi Shalom Shakna.<xref rid="fn91">91</xref> Shalom Shakna held a rabbinical post in Lublin and was the most eminent disciple of Jacob Pollack, who introduced the extreme pilpulistic method into halakic and talmudic studies.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.1
column2: Luria was recognized by his contemporaries as the salient authority on the Talmud and rabbinic law. His reputation as scholar and judge was firmly and widely established. Legal inquiries were addressed to him from all corners of the diaspora. Rabbi Isaac ben Bezalel wrote from Vladimir, "Your decision is as sound as the Mosaic Law."<xref rid="fn104">104</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.2
column2: Luria lived to realize a life-long aspiration—the establishment of a large body of students and disciples, who, impregnated with his originality and provocative scholarship, carried on with eminence his tradition of learning. Luria gloried in his proteges.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.3
column2: Appended is a list of several of his disciples who did credit to their inspiring master.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.4
column2: Luria not only left a lasting imprint on his own generation, but his voluminous works exerted a profound influence on posterity. Succeeding generations turned to Luria for guidance and illumination. His Hokmat Shelomoh has been appended to the editions of the Talmud, and subsequently many of his readings were incorporated in the text proper. His other works were referred to by the later halakists. Ezekiel ben Judah Landau, writing in the eighteenth century, thus pays homage to the majestic achievements of Luria: "No name lends greater sanctity to a code than that of Maharshal (Rabbi Solomon Luria). He even disputed the rishonim. His was the heart of a lion."105 Graetz in the nineteenth century calls him the Rabbenu Tam of the sixteenth century.106 Even today one synagogue in Lublin bears Luria's name (Maharschal Schul).107

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.5
column2: Appended also is an exhaustive list of his works, revealing the scope and extent of his contributions to the art and science of the law.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.6
column2: Luria died in Lublin on the second day of Kislev in the year 5334 (1573 C. E.). He left two sons and four daughters:

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.7
column2: Jehiel, who later became Chief Rabbi of Lublin; Zeeb Wolf; Sarah, wife of Judah, Chief Rabbi of (name of city lost); Valantina, wife of Ephraim Fishel, Chief Rabbi of Brest; Miriam, who married Eliezer of Cracow, brother of Moses Isserles; and another daughter (name unknown), who married Simon Wolf Auerbach, Chief Rabbi of Turban, Lublin, Przemysl, Vienna, Posen, and Prague.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.8
column2: The gravestone of Solomon Luria stands to this day in the old cemetery in the city of Lublin.<xref rid="fn108">108</xref> The front bears the inscription:

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.9
Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.10
column2: The inscription is continued on the back of the tombstone:

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.11
Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.12
column2: Here lies the noblest of the noble,

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.13
column2: The king of the wisest of teachers.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.14
column2: The great light who illuminated Israel for all time by his work

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.15
column2: Yam Shel Shelomoh and other works.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.16
column2: His name is known throughout the world.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.17
column2: He spread the law in all the gates, and reared many pupils….

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.18
column2: He reared pupils from all over the world;

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.19
column2: He was just and conscientious in all of his glorious deeds;

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.20
column2: His excellency Rabbi Solomon Luria, son of his excellency Rabbi Yehiel Luria.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.21
column2: He has been summoned as counsel before the academy on high.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Fame and Influence.22
column2: The second day of Kislev, 5334<xref rid="fn109">109</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Method of Study.1
column2: In contrast to the new pilpulistic method, Luria describes his own method of study:

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Method of Study.2
column2: "I trace the law to its ultimate source. I engage in an exhaustive research of all available authorities until I reach the very root of the matter. At times a full week is spent in the minute examination of a single point of law. I subject the validity of every decision to the closest scrutiny. All the pertinent precedents are collated before I formulate my own view. I supplement these studies with the opinions of my colleagues and students.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Method of Study.3
column2: "So thoroughly and intensively did I explore the law and its sources that in two years of constant and concentrated study I completed but one-half of the tractate Yebamot; two chapters of the tractate Ketubot consumed a full year; I devoted one-half year to the study of the chapter Mizwat Halizah."95

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Task.1
column2: Luria perceived the possibility of bringing stability into Jewish life. Law and order must be firmly established. Error in every form must be rigorously weeded out. The truth must be crystallized. Luria, well qualified, made his life work a continuous and religious devotion to the task, marked with severity toward the false and spurious, and profound appreciation of sound and traditional scholarship.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Task.2
column2: Appended are citations from one of Luria's works in which, among the glosses, appear his critical notes on the textual errors of the Talmud, Rashi, and the tosafists. It is called Hokmat Shelomoh (The Wisdom of Solomon).

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Task.3
column2: Luria was practically the first rabbi to introduce the scientific method of textual criticism of the Talmud and its commentaries.<xref rid="fn28">28</xref> He ridiculed the scholars who regarded old manuscripts as authentic and above criticism.<xref rid="fn29">29</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Luria's Task.4
column2: Of even greater significance and value is his compendium Yam shel Shelomoh (The Sea of Solomon), wherein he treats the talmudic law in his own way, entirely independent of his predecessors and contemporaries. To Luria, law was not merely a system for the maintenance of religion, social order, and the protection of individual rights, but also the bulwark of divine truth.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Maimonides.1
column2: Luria exalted Maimonides to the first rabbinic rank.51 He accordingly manifests a marked restraint in disparaging his work. He concedes that the opinion of Maimonides may not be ignored on questions on which the Talmud is silent.52 He refuses, however, to acknowledge the authenticity of the Mishneh Torah in its entirety. He is lavish in his praise of its style, method, and completeness. Its very artistry, however, Luria believed, misled Maimonides to treat his code as if it had been transmitted as a tradition of Moses from Mount Sinai and also, on that account, to omit the sources of the law. A code of laws without indicated sources was repugnant to Luria's conception of an authoritative corpus juris. Luria joins Semag (Moses ben Jacob of Coucy) in his characterization of Mishneh Torah as a "dream without an interpretation." Luria further maintained that the code of Maimonides was not free from error; and in support of his own findings he declared that Rabad III (Abraham ben David) in his polemics on Yad ha-Hazakah (another name for Mishneh Torah) found beyond doubt that Maimonides had committed many errors. Luria added that Maggid Mishneh (Rabbi Vidal of Tolosa)53 had often asserted that Maimonides erred, or with humility confessed that he could not fathom him.54

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Maimonides.2
column2: Luria pays tribute to the scientific accomplishments of Maimonides. He calls him the dean of natural scientists and physicians.55 He recognizes that the knowledge of natural science and medicine aided Maimonides in crystallizing truths concealed in the Talmud, particularly in the realm of terefah.56 To this expression of approval Luria adds a reservation: "A scientific doctrine in accord with religious beliefs and practice is not unworthy of notice. Such matters (Issur we-Heter), however, may not be predicated upon secular sciences."57

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Migdal Oz.1
