column2: In commenting upon the rulings of Migdal Oz (Shem-Tob ben Abraham ibn Gaon), Solomon Luria said: "Although Migdal Oz was a scholar and a talmudist, his opinions are strange, confusing, and erroneous. This can be attested by anyone who contrasts his long and quibbling decisions with the traditional law. His work is certainly his best judge. His decisions are by no means dependable. In cases where his decisions are confirmed by proof we depend upon the proof and not upon him."<xref rid="fn63">63</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Moses Isserles (Rema).1
column2: Luria set aside precedents unsupported by the Talmud, and rejected opinions of scholars based on what he deemed false conceptions of talmudic passages. His astute criticism caused great anxiety in the rabbinic world. Isserles, Luria's second cousin,68 was moved to question his power to overrule the authority of acknowledged halakists.69 But Luria was not dismayed. Answering Isserles, Luria says: "You wonder by what warrant I am empowered to bring certainty into the law. You impugn my authority to disagree with the codifiers. It is the knowledge of the law which invests me with the prerogative to take issue with the halakists and expose their errors. I refer you to the errors committed by Jacob Weil in Derashat Pessah, 157, and by Joseph Caro in Orah Hayyim, 498. You will discover more defects in the codes and works of the halakists if you consult my large work."70

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Moses Isserles (Rema).2
column2: On another occasion Luria writes to Isserles, "Even if you can establish that my decisions clash with those of the recent halakists, I still remain adamant. Nor shall I yield to your own opinions, which command the equal respect and authority accorded the opinions of the aharonim.<xref rid="fn71">71</xref> I shall acknowledge my error only in the event that you prove that my decisions are not founded on the Talmud, or that my line of reasoning is not supported by the early geonim."<xref rid="fn72">72</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Nahmanides.1
column2: Luria showed great reverence toward Nahmanides and considered him more impartial in his treatment of the French tosafists than was Maimonides. Nahmanides did not share with Maimonides the Spanish prejudice against the French commentators.<xref rid="fn58">58</xref> Nevertheless he criticized Nahmanides for expressing himself harshly against Baal haTerumah<xref rid="fn59">59</xref> (Baruk ben Isaac).

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Nissim Ben Reuben Gerundi.1
column2: The importance of Nissim ben Reuben Gerundi was minimized by Luria. Luria believed his fame at home and abroad as halakist and rabbinical authority unwarranted.<xref rid="fn64">64</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Pilpul.1
column2: Pilpul was one of the acknowledged talmudic methods of expounding the law. The pilpulists were masters of ingenious disputation and deduction. They possessed an inventive faculty for the formulation of doctrines which did not entirely depend for their validity upon tradition. The tosafists pursued this method in the study of the Talmud. Luria had studied pilpul in his youth.<xref rid="fn92">92</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Pilpul.2
column2: The end of the fifteenth century witnessed a radical transformation in the pilpulistic method. Undue emphasis was placed upon the perfection of the method as an end in itself, to the detriment of the halakic conclusion. It was no longer a mode of applying logical principles to the elucidation of the talmudic text. Pilpul became synonymous with quibble and degenerated into sophistry. Mental acrobatics yielded startling results. The method was better known now by its new name hillukim. The perversion attained its culmination in the Polish school inspired by Jacob Pollack.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Pilpul.3
column2: This change did not appeal to Luria. His keenly analytical mind severed the ethereal threads of the pilpulistic argument. He considered the over-refined pilpul as unworthy of application to the Talmud. He perceived no merit in drawing over-nice distinctions. He maintained that continuous hair-splitting dialectics led to the commission of elementary errors and to ultimate confusion in the law.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Pilpul.4
column2: He accordingly found it imperative to caution the student against the fallacies in the work of Shalom Shakna, chief exponent of pilpulism: "Do not be guided by his work.<xref rid="fn93">93</xref> He ensnares you with false premises and deceptive deductions. He strikes out that which is beyond the range of his comprehension and, in lieu thereof, contents himself with specious substitutes. I have already directed your attention to this practice on his part."<xref rid="fn94">94</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Post Talmudic Law Makers.1
column2: From its completion until the sixteenth century the Talmud had been the constant subject of discussion, interpretation, and application. It suffered in the process.<xref rid="fn23">23</xref> Scholars had distorted the meaning of talmudic passages to conform to their own views or to the exigencies of changing circumstances. Talmudic precedents were falsely established for laws and customs which not only did not have their roots in the Talmud but which were, moreover, alien to the spirit of its teachings; honest differences of opinion gave rise to conflicting doctrines and a devitalizing uncertainty. The Talmud was yielding to codices of questionable authenticity; a multiplicity of doubts threatened the uniformity of doctrine and the universal authority of the Talmud.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Rabbenu Bahya.1
column2: Rabbenu Bahya ben Asher's comment on the inverted nunin (Numbers 10:34-36), that these indicate the destruction of the world at the end of the fiftieth millennium, was characterized by Luria as a reverie deserving no attention whatsoever.62

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Rabbenu Tam.1
column2: He called Rabbenu Tam "holy mouth" and regarded him as a dialectician who knew how to discriminate between truth and error. Luria declared his opinions without inconsistency. With Rosh (Asher ben Jehiel) he proclaimed Rabbenu Tam superior to Maimonides as talmudic authority, favoring his opinions in the controversy with Rashi.<xref rid="fn41">41</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Rashba.1
column2: Luria maintained that the statement of Rashba (Solomon ben Abraham), later repeated by Joseph Colon in his responsa<xref rid="fn60">60</xref> in the name of Rashba—that Rabbenu Gershon intended the ban against bigamy to expire at the end of the fifth millennium (about 1240 C.E.)—was as baseless as a fleeting fancy. The morals of the present generation are no better than the morals in the days of Rabbenu Gershon; there is no ground for lifting the ban.<xref rid="fn61">61</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, Rashi.1
column2: Luria regarded the opinions of Rashi with great reverence, even in his controversies with the geonim.<xref rid="fn39">39</xref> However, he resolved conflicts between Rashi and Sheiltot in favor of the earlier gaonic view.<xref rid="fn40">40</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The French Tosafists.1
column2: Luria credits the early French tosafists with their contributions toward the clarification of the Talmud.42 He attributes particular significance to the literal meaning of "Piske Tosafot"—decisions of the tosafists—as implying the binding force of law, to be distinguished from academic treatises.43 He does not, however, unreservedly accept the exclusive authority of the tosafists upon questions of law in controversy. (cf. note 79.)

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The French Tosafists.2
column2: The later tosafists are treated less mildly. He charges them with creating further confusion in the law. He challenges their power to promulgate new laws or to rescind or modify established laws. Their continual controversies were distasteful to him. He criticized their failure to disclose the authoritative source of every decision.<xref rid="fn44">44</xref> He exposed the fact that the same decision was at times attributed to different tosafists and offered this as a clue to resultant inconsistencies. He objected to the statement of a decision prior to the presentation of the legal argument.<xref rid="fn45">45</xref> This led, he indicated, to mistaking the argument for the law. He described the style of the tosafists as fluctuating between two extremes, needlessly elaborated or terse to the point of abstruseness.<xref rid="fn46">46</xref> Luria deplored the anachronisms which had crept into the text.<xref rid="fn47">47</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The French Tosafists.3
column2: Evidently the work of the later tosafists did not advance the cause of unity and harmony in law.<xref rid="fn48">48</xref> Luria himself rejected a decision of a tosafist and, in the process, characterized it as a halting utterance to which neither Rosh nor Rif (Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi) attached any weight.<xref rid="fn49">49</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Geonim.1
column2: In dealing, however, with post-talmudic legal literature, Luria dared to distinguish between tradition and innovation, between the authentic and the spurious. It is fundamental with him that supreme authority was not vested in the doctors of law of the post-talmudic era. He treats the geonim with reverence but not on an equal level with the talmudic teachers. "The decision of a gaon may not be opposed, for it is traditional."31 "A decision at variance with an explicit holding of a gaon is as void as if rendered contrary to an expressed provision in the Mishnah."32 "The decisions of the geonim are free from error and inconsistency."33 "Even inadvertence may not be imputed to the geonim."34 Luria held that he who contradicts the traditional opinions of the geonim disqualifies himself as an authority on rabbinic law.35 He adheres to the Sheiltot, relying upon the dicta of the aharonim that its decisions are traditional and hence not subject to controversion.36 He accordingly follows Rabbenu Hananeel, not a gaon, because his decisions are predicated upon tradition.37 It is because Luria does not accord the full sanction of tradition to Yalkut Shimoni, that he reserves the privilege to dissent from its interpretations.38

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Laity.1
column2: The masses and the congregation are not spared the fate of the rabbis; they too become the subject of Luria's attacks. Luria does not moderate his opinions.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Laity.2
column2: "I condemn the youth who frequent dance-halls on the Sabbath and on the holidays. The practice is forbidden even if the music is furnished by gentile musicians. Moreover, those who participate in these revelries are doomed to mental and physical degeneracy. For at such boisterous gatherings they imbibe freely and indulge in sexual indecencies."<xref rid="fn81">81</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Laity.3
column2: On another occasion the German Jews are made the butt of his criticism:

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Laity.4
column2: "I shall disclose the perverse nature of the German Jews. A Jew of wealth and power is not censured for drinking pagan wine or for eating fish prepared in gentile utensils. He is, on the contrary, accorded the honors befitting a pious Jew. And though they condone these serious transgressions of the law they attach an undeserving and exaggerated importance to trifles. Eating or studying the Talmud while the head is uncovered is regarded by them as an act of apostasy."<xref rid="fn82">82</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Laity.5
column2: Nor does he withhold criticism of the members of his own congregation. He rebuked them for their factional altercations, and particularly for using the synagogue as a means of aggression against one another.<xref rid="fn83">83</xref> He expressed displeasure with the cantors selected by the congregations, in the following statement:

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Laity.6
column2: "The law requires that the rabbi choose the cantor from among his students.<xref rid="fn84">84</xref> Should the rabbi dare exercise this right his selection would be rejected by the congregation. It would be idle for the rabbi to protest. The congregations retain to themselves and withhold from the rabbis the power of appointment, in order that the cantor remain accountable to them alone, free from rabbinic supervision or control. As a consequence, the piety of the cantor is subordinated to a pleasant voice and clear delivery."<xref rid="fn85">85</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Professional Rabbis.1
column2: Luria speaks with asperity of the professional rabbis of his time. "Because of the increasing ignorance of the rabbis, it has become customary for the laymen to resort to arbitration for settlement of their civil suits."<xref rid="fn73">73</xref> Even greater acrimony is expressed in the following statement: "The reason some of the modern rabbis are strict in matrimonial disputes is that they seek to prolong litigation and cause the cases to be transferred from one rabbi to another, in order to fill their coffers and those of their secretaries with ill-gotten fees. Their claim that no law was ever declared prohibiting a rabbi from following the stricter practice does not excuse them from causing unjustifiable suffering among people. Behold, the Jewish religion will not tolerate such things."<xref rid="fn74">74</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Professional Rabbis.2
column2: Luria deprived the rabbis of a right awarded to them, according to their opinion, by Rambam and Rosh. The two halakists ruled that he who insults a talmid hakam must pay him a fine of a gold pound.75 Rambam did not define the term, but according to Rosh, every rabbi and every ordained person is deemed a talmid hakam.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Professional Rabbis.3
column2: Luria traced the ruling to Talmud Yerushalmi,76 which states: "He who insults a zaken has to pay him a fine of a gold pound." This ruling, Luria argued, is not applicable to present day rabbis. The zaken mentioned in Yerushalmi refers to a scholar of profound erudition who is principally preoccupied in the study of the law, and to whom the business of earning a livelihood is secondary. He must not, of course, neglect his family or himself, but he must not accumulate wealth. His time must not be spent in idleness or in earthly pleasures. And above all he must be universally held in esteem.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Professional Rabbis.4
column2: Such rabbis nowadays, Luria continued, are very rare. The ordained are many but the learned are few. The haughty are increasing; none knows his place. Immediately upon ordination the rabbis assume a pompous air. They flaunt their wealth and assemble disciples as lords hire slaves to run before them. Our zekenim are old in years but not in wisdom. Some of them have not mastered even the general practice of the law. Nevertheless, they rule over congregations and over scholars. They excommunicate and anathematize. They ordain pupils who did not study under them, for valuable considerations received. They seek their own interests. Even the rare scholar conducts himself disgracefully. He delivers formal discourses in order to display his scholarly attainments and not with the intention of disseminating knowledge. This is now the practice of all rabbis. Moreover, they hold up to contempt and ridicule that extraordinary rabbi who is engrossed in the study of the Law and is scrupulous in the observance of the ritual.

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Professional Rabbis.5
column2: "Therefore, the fine must be abolished. I have often witnessed the excitement which accompanied the imposition of the fine; the masses became noisy; they mocked and jeered the court. They jested that the only reason for entering the rabbinate was to collect the gold pound. It has even become common, at the outset of an argument, for one of the adversaries to ask of the other: Do you want me to insult you in order that you may collect the gold pound from me?

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Professional Rabbis.6
column2: "In any event, where the gold pound may be imposed in exceptional instances the proceeds should be divided among the poor."<xref rid="fn77">77</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Study of Philosophy.1
column2: Luria felt that the study of philosophy retarded and corrupted the cause of law. He criticized Maimonides for having recommended to his son the philosophic works of Abraham ibn Ezra, and ridiculed the belief expressed by Maimonides that philosophy is the gateway to wisdom, perfection, and eternity.<xref rid="fn96">96</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Study of Philosophy.2
column2: Greek philosophy was particularly obnoxious to him. He regarded it as destructive and perversive of the law. He rebuked Isserles for injecting Aristotelian philosophy into the interpretation of the law, and counseled him against the further pursuit of Greek thought. "I advise you to study grammar (as a diversion), a knowledge which is essential and which will avail you much more than the study of philosophy."<xref rid="fn97">97</xref>

column1: Meir, Solomon Luria, The Talmud.1
column2: The Talmud (Gemara) had been accepted as the sole and ultimate authority of the law. Luria found the sanction of the talmudic text impaired and weakened. It was his aim to restore its authority, relying upon the dicta found within the bounds of the Talmud. Its authority, Luria said, was even greater than that of the Mishnah and Baraita. "The Mishnah that has talmudic commentaries is more authentic than one without commentaries of the Talmud."21 "The text for decisions is not the Mishnah, nor the Baraita, but the Gemara."22 His was a difficult task, calling for independence and courage, and utter confidence in the correctness of his judgment.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Al Ha Nissim(xlviii).1
column2: Q. If one has omitted Al ha-nissim on Purim in the grace after meals, does he have to repeat the grace?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Al Ha Nissim(xlviii).2
column2: A. Although no repetition is required if it is omitted in the morning or evening prayer, the paragraph must be repeated if omitted in the grace after meals, for the meal of Purim is an institution established by the prophets and sages for all time to come, and it must be kept with the strictness of any other biblical law.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Amen(xliv).1
column2: Q. Is the amen after the third benediction of Boneh Yerushalaim in grace after meals to be said aloud or in an undertone? (Boneh Yerushalaim ends that part of grace which is to be recited according to the Bible; the rest is added through a rabbinic ordinance).

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Amen(xliv).2
column2: A. The reason that in talmudic times14 the amen after Boneh Yerushalaim was spoken in a whisper is that the workers be not disturbed in the middle of grace. They used to have their meals together with their master, and if he had said amen aloud, they would have taken this as token that grace was finished, and that they had to return to work.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Amen(xliv).3
column2: Another reason is that the teachers wanted to impress upon their pupils, dining with them, that this was not the end of grace, lest they begin to talk with one another, and fail to observe the fourth benediction Hatob we-ha-metib with respect.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Amen(xliv).4
column2: Nowadays, however, workers, by agreement with their employers, have the right to pray three times a day, to say grace after meals, and to read the Shema and they would not be sent back to work after their meal without finishing grace. The students, at this time, need no such instruction either, because they know the meaning of the amen. Therefore, this amen, like any other, should be said aloud.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Anenu(lxiii).1
column2: The reader in the synagogue had forgotten to say Anenu on a public fast day before Refaenu. He was reminded by the officer in charge when he had already begun the benediction Refaenu and was advised to say the Anenu in the passage Shomea Tefilah, where it is recited in individual prayer. But he forgot it again and said the benediction Shomea Tefilah as always.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Anenu(lxiii).2
column2: Q. Shall he then say it after oseh shalom as a special benediction, or shall it be said before Elohai nezor as in individual prayers, if he failed to say it in the right place?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Anenu(lxiii).3
column2: A. It should be said before Elohai nezor, and it will not be considered a distinct benediction although recited after the conclusion of the Eighteen Benedictions.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).1
column2: Covering the head became one of the strict religious practices among the people. They would not pray nor walk in the open air with their heads uncovered. In course of time even having the head uncovered in the house was regarded as a sacrilegious act. They would not eat nor sleep with bare heads.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).2
column2: The following question was then sent to Luria:

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).3
column2: Q. May one who has a headache eat bareheaded?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).4
column2: A. I know of no prohibition against saying the benedictions with an uncovered head. I do not know on what ground Isserlein prohibited pronouncing the name of God bareheaded. In the treatise Soferim a controversy is recorded as to whether the Shema may be recited by one whose head is uncovered.8 Rabbenu Jeruham (ben Meshullam) holds that no benediction may be said with the head uncovered.9 But if any of the great scholars would support me I should overrule them and permit the recital of the benedictions and even the Shema with the head bare. It is distinctly understood from Midrash Rabbah10 that it is not forbidden to proclaim the Shema with an uncovered head. On the contrary, the Midrash Rabbah's contrast of God with a temporal king clearly indicates that it is even more dignified to read the Shema with an uncovered head, because it manifests greater reverence, than to read it with a covered head. But as the Jewish religion prefers tranquillity and simplicity in its services, the Jews were excused from worshiping God in that pompous and pretentious manner in which kings are honored by their peoples. However, such services were never prohibited by the ancients. Yet, I cannot permit myself to say the Shema bareheaded, because this has been accepted by the people as prohibited.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).5
column2: But it is surprising why they declared a prohibition against having the head uncovered even when they do not pray. Such a rule was ordered for women only.<xref rid="fn119">11</xref> The statement by Rabbi Huna ben Rabbi Joshua: "May it come home to me that I never walk a distance of four cubits with my head uncovered" (i.e., he believed to have merited divine reward therefore), which is mentioned in the Talmud,<xref rid="fn120">12</xref> was not intended to establish a law for all the people, but merely to tell how a scrupulously faithful rabbi expressed his loving obedience to the will of God. The Talmud prohibited proud carriage,<xref rid="fn121">13</xref> but it never prohibited walking bareheaded. And nowadays the order is reversed. Proud carriage is not considered forbidden at all; the haughty and the rich walk proudly with their necks stretched forth, but they would not dare walk bareheaded, not for the sake of piety but because they believe that this is a Jewish rite.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).6
column2: There is no law which prohibits one to pronounce the name of God or to walk in the open air bareheaded. This was the conduct of the extremely pious people only. Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi objected only to allowing the people to walk into the synagogue bareheaded. Jacob ben Asher ruled that during public worship the people must have their heads covered and not during the reading of the Shema at home. But I cannot fly in the face of the people; they prohibited it and I have no right to defy them.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).7
column2: Therefore, the scholar should be careful not to study with his head uncovered, lest the people consider him irreverent and licentious, as if he had broken a Jewish law. He should even be careful in his private room, for some ignoramus might drop in on him even there and scornfully criticise him. Whenever the scholars have forbidden a thing for appearance's sake, it is forbidden even in the strictest privacy.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Bareheadedness(lxxii).8
column2: A man who suffers from a headache which is aggravated by a heavy covering of the head, should cover it with a cap made of fine linen or silk. But if one wants to eat at night and his head is uncovered, or if one wants to drink while taking a bath, he may say the benediction by covering the head with his hand.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Call to the Torah(lxxi).1
column2: It is customary to call a father to the Torah on the same Sabbath on which he has to circumcise his son. On the other hand, a mourner is not called to the Torah on Sabbath. A mourner who begot a son that was to be circumcised on Sabbath asked:

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Call to the Torah(lxxi).2
column2: Q. May he be called to the Torah on that Sabbath?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Call to the Torah(lxxi).3
column2: A. The law does not actually require calling the father who is to circumcise his son on the Sabbath to the Torah; therefore, he should not be called when he is in mourning. This would not appear as mourning in public, which is not permitted on Sabbath, because as not everybody is called to the Torah on every Sabbath, the congregation would not notice that he was not called to the Torah on account of mourning.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).1
column2: Q. Someone asked Luria whether he was familiar with the tradition concerning the contents and order of the prayer book.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).2
column2: A. I have received no particular tradition from my late grandfather with regard to services. In my youth I concentrated my whole attention on the study of the Talmud and dialectics, and to my sorrow and regret I neglected the study of liturgy. My grandfather's library, including his prayer book, to which I could turn for reference, was destroyed in the great fire of Posen. Alas, it is gone and cannot be replaced!

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).3
column2: Yet I remember somewhat vaguely the style in which my grandfather used to pray. It differed in many respects from that which I have found in various prayer books.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).4
column2: The following are the differences:

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).5
column2: When he prayed alone he said Anenu immediately after Al teshibenu rekam milfaneka, and finished the paragraph with Baruk atah Adonai shomea tefilah, and not with ha-oneh be-et zarah.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).6
column2: When it happened that he came late to the synagogue, in the middle of the service, he skipped all portions of the prayer except Baruk she-amar, Ashre, and Yishtabah; or he would sometimes skip these portions also and join the congregation. After the prayer he never said pesuke de-zimrah. In the morning he recited the Decalogue from Exodus, 20:2-14, and at night on his bed, after having read Shema, the Decalogue from Deuteronomy 5:6-18.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).7
column2: In counting the Omer he used to say Ha-yom shene yamim, ha-yom sheloshah yamim, omitting the word ba-omer. In the Al ha-nissim he said ba-yamim ha-hem ba-zeman ha-zeh, and not u-ba-zeman ha-zeh. The omission of the u implied that the miracles were performed in days of old, at that time, and not at this time.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).8
column2: The second night of Sukkot he used to say lesheb ba-sukkah before shehehianu, just as on the first night.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).9
column2: In the prayer Hashkibenu he omitted the word oyeb because it is included in the words deber we-hereb.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).10
column2: In order to be sure that he would not omit a word in the section Pitum ha-ketoret while praying, he never read it by heart. He interpreted the rule We-im hissar ahat mi-kol samaneha hayyab mitah as referring to the prayer itself, which is now substituting for the sacrifice.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).11
column2: In grace after meals he omitted the word borenu from the passage ha-El, abinu, malkenu, adirenu, borenu, goalenu, yozrenu, either because the terms borenu and yozrenu connote the same thing, creation, or because, while the term yazar applies to material creation, the term bara denotes spiritual creation, and does not suit the occasion of eating.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).12
column2: He finished the section of Ha-rahaman with the phrase we-imru amen and not with we-nomar amen.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).13
column2: The following are the emendations which I made in the liturgical procedure:

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).14
column2: After washing the hands in the morning, I say asher yazar. Immediately thereafter I recite Elohai neshamah, leaving the benediction al netilat yadayim to be said at the synagogue. After the benediction of the Torah, I add three verses from the Pentateuch (Leviticus, 19:16-18), three verses from the Prophets (Joshua, 1:7-9), three verses from the Hagiographa (Psalms, 1:1-3), and the Mishnah Elu debarim she-en la-hem shiur (Peah 1:1). Thus I indicate that the benediction of the Torah includes the Mishnah. (The other sections tally with the order of our prayer books.)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).15
column2: In the benedictions of the morning I omit the phrases magbiha shefalim and hanoten la-yaef koah, because they are not mentioned in the Talmud nor in the works of the geonim. I say matir asurim before zokef kefufim. I say the second Yiheyu le-razon, which was composed by Rabbi Judah ha-Nasi after Elohai nezor, and finish the section with yiheyu le-razon imre fi.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).16
column2: I say the Shema of le-fikak by Rabbi Judah ha-Nasi up to u-bishareka, and then I say mekadesh et shimka ba-rabim. Before Baruk she-amar I recite the Decalogue in a loud voice. (The other sections tally with those of our prayer books.) I skip the first two verses of Ashre and begin with Tehilah le-David, and say the first of these two verses at the afternoon service. I finish the section with the verse Tehilat Adonai yedaber, and omit wa-anahnu nebarek Jah.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).17
column2: In the morning when I come to the synagogue I start praying with the verse Wa-ani be-rob hasdeka and skip the verse Mah tobu ohaleka, because Balaam said it, and his intent was to curse the Israelites and not to bless them. I also omit the verse Wa-ani tefilati, but say it on Sabbath at the afternoon prayer.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).18
column2: When the morning prayer is over I sit down and say: Ashre yoshbe beteka and Ashre ha-am. Before leaving the synagogue I say while sitting, Ak zadikim yodu li-shemeka yeshbu yesharim et paneka; then I stand, bow down, face the ark, and say: Ki kol ha-amim yelku ish be-shem Elohaw ma-anahnu nelek be-shem Adonai Elohenu le-olam waed. On leaving the synagogue I bow down again and say: Neheni Adonai be-zidkatka lemaan shorerai hayeshar le-fanai darkeka.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).19
column2: When the reader sings Bareku, I say Yitbarak up to berakah u-tefilah; when he sings the Shem, I say Baruk shem kebod malkuto le-olam waed; when he sings ha-meborak, I say yehi shem Adonai meborak meatah we-ad olam; and when the reader finishes ha-meborak, I say Baruk Adonai ha-meborak le-olam waed.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).20
column2: I do not say El melek neeman before the Shema. On the anniversary of my father's death, when I act as the reader, I conclude the Shema with the phrase Ani Adonai Elohekem and omit the word emet. Before the Eighteen Benedictions I say Adonai sefatai tiftah u-fi yagid tehilateka. I do not say Refaenu Adonai Elohenu but Refaenu Adonai we-nerafe. I do not say Reeh na be-anyenu but Reeh be-anyenu. I say we-sabeenu mi-tubeka and not we-sabeenu mitubah. Before a fast day I say Hareni be-taanit yahid mahar le-faneka. Before and after Elohai nezor I say Malkenu Elohenu, and finish the Eighteen Benedictions with Aseh lemaan shemeka which was said by Samuel, and yehi le-razon shetazilenu ha-yom u-be-kol yom which was said by Rabbi Judah ha-Nasi.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).21
column2: I say Bameh madlikin every Sabbath, even when a holiday falls on Friday. In the prayer El Adon, I say Baruk u-meborak befi kol neshamah, omitting the word hu in order to have five words in this line as in the preceding one. And I say hesed we-rahamim lifne kebodo and not kise kebodo, because the word kise is used in the line zekut u-mishor lifne kiseo.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Contents and Order of Prayer Book(lxiv).22
column2: The right formula for Shemini Azeret is et shemini azeret hag ha-zeh. For the celebration of the seder on Passover night I have composed a short table with my name on it, and I have composed a tehinah which has been copied in many prayer books.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Priority of Benediction(xcvii).1
column2: One forgot to say the benediction bore nefashot after his luncheon. Meanwhile he passed water, and just before he recited the benediction asher yazar he reminded himself that he had not yet uttered the benediction after his luncheon.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Priority of Benediction(xcvii).2
column2: Q. Which of the two benedictions should he say first?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, Priority of Benediction(xcvii).3
column2: A. He should say first the benediction asher yazar; the more frequent always takes precedence.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Benediction of Searching For Leaven(lxxxvi).1
column2: Q. Which is the correct formula of the benediction for searching the leaven, al biur or le-baer?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Benediction of Searching For Leaven(lxxxvi).2
column2: A. Either formula is correct, because either one expresses the future tense. However, al biur was accepted in practice in order to correct the wrong impression of the people, who thought that al biur expresses the past tense.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Beverage At Grace After Meals(xxiii).1
column2: Q. Is it permissible to use any kind of beverage for the cup at the grace after meals?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Beverage At Grace After Meals(xxiii).2
column2: A. Yes, but only when wine or beer is not obtainable. Yet this information should be kept from the public, lest they make of it a general rule and apply it even when these beverages are procurable.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Beverage At Grace After Meals(xxiii).3
Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).1
column2: Q. In what order ought the Torah benediction be said in the morning prayers?

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).2
column2: A. Ancient custom placed it before the section of the tamid, and the old prayer books were arranged accordingly. The Tur (Jacob ben Asher), however, placed it immediately after the benediction al netilat yadayim, so as to precede the scriptural verses of the birkat kohanim.

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).3
column2: I, however, recite the morning prayer in the following order: The benediction of the Torah I say at home right after the washing of the hands, having first said asher yazar and Elohai neshamah (the benediction of netilat yadayim I say at the synagogue). After the benediction of the Torah I say:

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).4
column2: Three verses of Leviticus—19:16-18 (Law)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).5
column2: Three verses of Joshua—1:7-9 (Prophets)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).6
column2: Three verses of Psalms—1:1-3 (Hagiographa)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).7
column2: Peah—1:1 (Mishnah)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).8
column2: Leviticus—28:1-8 (Mikra)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).9
column2: Zebahim—5:1-7 (Mishnah)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).10
column2: Rabbi Ishmael, Baraita; beginning of Sifra (Talmud)

column1: Meir, V Benedictions and Prayers, The Torah Benediction(lvi).11
column2: Birkat Kohanim—Numbers 6:24-26 (Torah)

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Inverted Nunin(lxxiii).1
column2: Q. How is the scribe to act with regard to the inverted nunin (letter N) found in Numbers 10:35, 36, and with the additional nunin, inserted by some scribes?

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Inverted Nunin(lxxiii).2
column2: A. I have found twelve different forms in the many Torah Scrolls I have examined; four of these forms are kosher, two are kosher but ought to be corrected, the other six forms make the Sefer Torah unholy and useless (pasul), unless erased and written in the correct form.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Inverted Nunin(lxxiii).3
column2: The following are the twelve forms:

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Inverted Nunin(lxxiii).4
Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Laying Tefillin(xcviii).1
column2: With the rise of the kabalistic school people began to mysticize religious practices. They spun their arguments into niceties, detailing them so minutely that even great scholars were misled and could not detect their fallacies. Not infrequently they encroached upon the realm of law, seeking to change it by mystic interpretation. A definite case was brought to the attention of Luria by Mordecai ben Tanhum.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Laying Tefillin(xcviii).2
column2: Q. Is it proper to don the tefillin shel yad while sitting, as maintained by some people?

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Laying Tefillin(xcviii).3
column2: A. This practice was originated by the kabalists, who see significance in every petty thing; they pretend to know the mysticism of the Zohar while deficient in rabbinics. Have no recourse to them, but follow the teaching of the Talmud and the accredited rabbinical authorities. Were Rabbi Simeon ben Yohai himself present with us this day we would not incline our ear to him, for he (the Zohar) decided in many cases against the customs of the ancients. The practice of donning the tefillin shel yad while sitting is not mentioned in the Talmud nor in post-talmudic literature. And I have a tradition from my great father-in-law Rabbi Kalonymus to don both the tefillin shel yad and the tefillin shel rosh while standing.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Laying Tefillin(xcviii).4
Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).1
column2: A competent scribe of Ruthenia, Little Russia, in writing the parshiyot of the tefillin shel yad, left a hiatus at the end of the parashah of Shema, and commenced the next parashah, We-hayah im shamoa, at the beginning of the first line on the next column, in accordance with the style of the German school. Thus, he made the later parashah open (petuhah). Rabbi Moses ben Meshullam, who had ordered the tefillin from the scribe, belonged to the Spanish school. The scribes of that school used to write the same parashah closed (setumah). He, therefore, thought that the tefillin were unholy and useless (pasul). A correspondence concerning this matter went on for some time among the following rabbis: Moses ben Meshullam, Joshua Shunzo, Meir ben Isaac Kazenellenbogen, and David Blumish, until it was submitted by Rabbi Moses Blumish to Luria.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).2
column2: Q. Should such tefillin as written by the scribe of Ruthenia be rejected?

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).3
column2: A. Tefillin written in this style are used throughout Russia and Germany. The scribes of these countires write the tefillin as prescribed by Ha-Baruk, that the parashah of Shema finish in the middle of the line. This ruling is in concurrence with that of Baal ha-Ittur, who holds that all the four parshiyot should be open, and it corresponds with that of Sefer Orhot Hayyim who ruled against Rambam, that such tefillin are kosher.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).4
column2: Therefore, I consider the tefillin written by that scribe kosher and preferable to the other styles which I have examined. Below are the various styles which I have looked over:

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).5
column2: 1. The first two parshiyot began at the top of each column and ended in the middle of the last line of the column. The parashah of Shema began at the top of the column and ended with a complete line at the end of the column. The parashah We-hayah im shamoa began in the middle of the first line.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).6
column2: 2. The first two parshiyot began in the middle of the line and ended with a full line at the end of the column. The parashah of Shema tallies with the one in number 1. The parashah We-hayah im shamoa opened at the beginning of the line and ended with a complete line.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).7
column2: 3. Each of the first three parshiyot commenced with the beginning of the first line and ended in the middle of the line at the end of each respective column, and the parashah We-hayah im shamoa began at the top of the column and ended with a full line.

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).8
column2: The tefillin which I prefer to all others are written in the following style:

column1: Meir, Vi Sefer Torah and Tefillin, Writing of Tefillin(xxxvii).9
column2: 4. The first parashah Kadesh begins with a full line at the top of the column and ends in the middle of the last line. The second parashah We-hayah ki yebiaka begins with a hiatus of three letters in the first line, and ends the last line with hiatus of nine letters. The third parashah of Shema begins the same way as the second, and ends with a full line. And the fourth parashah of We-hayah im shamoa begins the first line with a hiatus of at least three letters, and ends with a full last line. This style is prescribed by Rashi.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Catching Chickens on the Sabbath(x).1
column2: Q. Is it permitted on the Sabbath to chase after chickens in the house in order to catch them?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Catching Chickens on the Sabbath(x).2
column2: A. It is permitted to catch chickens on the Sabbath in the house, but it is not allowed to run after them in a large yard in order to catch them.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Effect of Visitors on Erub(xviii).1
column2: Q. Do the Jewish merchants who come to the fairs of Lublin, and as a matter of course fail to participate in the erub, curtail the right of Jewish settlers there to carry things on the Sabbath within the city limits?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Effect of Visitors on Erub(xviii).2
column2: Moses Isserles, who asked the question, was inclined to allow this, because he held that visitors, before they have stayed in the city thirty days, cannot curtail the right of the citizens; and the merchants who come to Lublin to the fairs do not stay there for thirty consecutive days.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Effect of Visitors on Erub(xviii).3
column2: A. Luria, on the other hand, ruled that the Jewish merchants who come to the fairs of Lublin do curtail the rights of the Jews living there permanently, because people who come to a place regularly have the rights of citizens and not of visitors. And the Jewish merchants come regularly to the fairs of Lublin. Even two merchants living in two houses facing one yard must have an erub in order to enjoy the right of carrying things on the Sabbath in the yard.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Egg Baked in the Sun on the Sabbath(lxi).1
column2: Q. Is it permissible to place an egg on a hot roof on the Sabbath in order to have it baked, since the heat of the sun and not the fire is the agent? Again, is it permitted to put an egg into hot sand on Friday, in order that it be roasted for the Sabbath?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Egg Baked in the Sun on the Sabbath(lxi).2
column2: A. The raw egg may be placed on the hot roof on the Sabbath, provided there is no hot dust. But eggs may not be put in hot sand on Friday to be used on the Sabbath. Even if the egg be already roasted, it must not be put into the sand to keep it hot for the Sabbath.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Erub(li).1
column2: Q. Is it permissible in a place where there is no erub to carry articles through the street on the Sabbath by passing them along from one person to another, standing within four cubits apart?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Erub(li).2
column2: A. This is not permitted.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Gentiles Working For a Jew on the Sabbath(c).1
column2: A Jew who held a concession from a gentile for a year, to manufacture and refine salt for him, hired gentiles for the year to boil the salt. They were not to be paid by the day, but by the quantity of the salt they produced. The vessels, however, belonged to the Jew.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Gentiles Working For a Jew on the Sabbath(c).2
column2: Q. May he allow his gentile laborers to work on the Sabbath?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Gentiles Working For a Jew on the Sabbath(c).3
column2: A. Your emphasis that the vessels belonged to the Jew is of no significance in the question. There is no law that vessels of a Jew must rest on the Sabbath. Therefore, since the gentiles were not hired to do the work on the Sabbath but to produce a certain quantity of salt, they are considered to be working for themselves and they have the right to choose for their rest day either the Sabbath or Sunday. If they choose to rest on Sunday, they may work on the Sabbath, provided the factory is outside the Jewish quarter.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Keeping Boiled Food Hot For the Sabbath(lx).1
column2: Q. Is it permissible to place hot boiled food in hot ashes on Friday so as to keep it warm for the Sabbath?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Keeping Boiled Food Hot For the Sabbath(lx).2
column2: A. Yes, it is permissible; because the hot ashes add no heat. But I have heard that in some localities people place their pots of hot boiled food on Friday on live coal, to keep them hot for the Sabbath. This is unquestionably not allowed, and measures ought to be taken to prevent them from so doing. In a closed oven, such a practice is questionable, even though the live coal and the ashes be moved away from the pot. Yet, in the latter case, if the people are so accustomed to it that they would not abandon it in the face of warning, no preventive measures have to be taken, since the Sefer-ha-Terumah (by Baruk ben Isaac ha-Kohen, twelfth century) and the Semag allow it.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Milking on the Sabbath(lxxv).1
column2: Q. a) May the milk milked on the Sabbath by a gentile be used the next day if it was a holiday (text: Pentecost) ?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Milking on the Sabbath(lxxv).2
column2: A. a) The milk may not be used for the holiday.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Milking on the Sabbath(lxxv).3
column2: Q. b) May the milk milked by a gentile the first day of a holiday be used the same day?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Milking on the Sabbath(lxxv).4
column2: A. b) The milk may be used on the same day.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Mukzeh I(xxxix).1
column2: A present was given by a gentile to a Jew on the first day of a holiday. The gentile had in all likelihood done some work on it on the same day.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Mukzeh I(xxxix).2
column2: Q. May another Jew make use of it on the second day of the holiday or not?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Mukzeh I(xxxix).3
column2: A. The gift given to a Jew by a gentile on the first day of a holiday may be used by another Jew on the second day of the holiday. Moreover, he would be allowed to use it even on the evening of the same day, provided he waited after dusk as long as it would take to procure it from the nearest place.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Mukzeh Ii(xl).1
column2: Q. May the knife used in circumcision on the Sabbath be handled or hidden away after the operation?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Mukzeh Ii(xl).2
column2: A. Handling of the knife designated for a circumcision on the Sabbath cannot be forbidden after the operation for the rest of the day, as handling of the Shofar cannot be forbidden after the services.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Preparing Food on a Holiday For the Sabbath(lxxviii).1
column2: One provided an erub, which permits preparing meals for the Sabbath on a holiday occurring on a Friday.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Preparing Food on a Holiday For the Sabbath(lxxviii).2
column2: Q. May he also slaughter an animal on that Friday, to use the meat on the Sabbath? In other words, does the erub that permits cooking on holidays for the Sabbath also include slaughtering?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Preparing Food on a Holiday For the Sabbath(lxxviii).3
column2: A. Since the erub specifies only cooking, baking, and lighting candles, slaughtering is not permitted. Even weak and delicate people ought to be denied the privilege of slaughtering on the holiday for the use of the Sabbath, in order to prevent them from sharpening the knives and from covering the blood with earth, not prepared before the holiday. Should the slaughtering be distinctly mentioned in the erub it would be permitted.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Shebut(xlvi).1
column2: The Talmud states that the rule of shebut (which prohibits a Jew asking a gentile to work for him on the Sabbath) does not apply to Friday at twilight.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Shebut(xlvi).2
column2: Q. Does it hold for any act at all, or only when a religious requisite or a matter of great importance is involved?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Shebut(xlvi).3
column2: A. The statement of the Talmud referred to applies only to acts of religious significance, as providing food, drink, clothes, or candles for the Sabbath. The gentiles may also be asked to light a Yahrzeit candle, which is customary among the German Jews. But acts which have a purely secular purpose are prohibited, unless they are of great moment or their omission might cause a great loss.

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Wearing Amulets on the Sabbath(xlvii).1
column2: Q. May youths wear their amulets on the Sabbath in a karmelit, if both the person who made the amulet and the amulet itself have not been approved by an acknowledged authority?

column1: Meir, Vii Sabbath, Wearing Amulets on the Sabbath(xlvii).2
column2: A. Although amulets are not efficacious, yet since those who wear them to ward off evil spirits or to cure epilepsy regard them also as ornaments, they may wear them on the Sabbath in a karmelit.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Burning the Leaven(lxxxvii).1
column2: Q. At what time and at what place should the leaven be burned on the eve of Passover?

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Burning the Leaven(lxxxvii).2
column2: A. The burning of the leaven must be done before noon, i.e., before 12 o'clock. And it should take place outside the house, for no benefit is to be derived therefrom, as for example, warming the home.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Business on Intermediary Days of a Holiday(lxxix).1
column2: Q. a) May business be transacted on hol ha-moed, particularly when the principal fairs occur during these days?

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Business on Intermediary Days of a Holiday(lxxix).2
column2: A. a) It is permitted to conduct business on hol ha-moed when a principal fair, or even a special fair, occurs during these days. Otherwise, one is allowed to do business on hol ha-moed by keeping the doors of the store partly closed; and the merchandise sold must be for the use of the holiday only.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Conducting the Seder(lxxxviii).1
column2: In order to assist the people in conducting the seder in the right order without spending too much time studying its arrangement, Luria composed a mnemonic table which indicated the details of the procedure. The table is a digest of the laws governing the seder and was written in acrostic style. The initials of certain words taken in order form his own name, the name of his father and the name of his grandfather: Shelomoh ben Rabbi Yehiel Luria, Shelomoh Rabbi Isaac.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Hallah(lviii).1
column2: One had forgotten to take hallah from the mazah dough.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Hallah(lviii).2
column2: Q. How should the hallah be taken from the baked mazot?

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Hallah(lviii).3
column2: A. All the mazot should be placed in a hamper, and one mazah be taken out as hallah.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Hamez.1
column2: Q. b) If a grain of wheat was found on the mazah dough, would it turn the dough into hamez?

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Hamez.2
column2: Q. c) If a grain of wheat was found on salted meat, may the meat be used on Passover?

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Hamez.3
column2: A. (b and c) the dough and the meat must be considered leaven and should be burned.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Hamez.4
column2: Note: the three questions were submitted to Luria by Solomon ben Judah.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Mazot Touching One Another(lvii).1
column2: Citing the laws of leaven with regard to the baking of mazot, the Terumat ha-Deshen by Israel Isserlein states: She-be-Pessah yesh le-esor kol ha-mazot.16 Scholars not well versed in the law interpreted the statement to mean that when two mazot touch each other in the oven while baking, all the mazot in the oven become leaven. The question was sent to Luria.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Mazot Touching One Another(lvii).2
column2: Q. Do two mazot which touched one another in the oven while baking become leaven only in the contiguous parts or in the whole? Or, perhaps, do all the mazot in the oven baked at the time become leaven? Would it make any difference as to when they were baked, before or during Passover?

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Mazot Touching One Another(lvii).3
column2: A. We have a tradition to prohibit mazot for Passover use if they were folded up in the oven while baking, but the mazot which touched one another do not become leaven at all. And there is no difference when they were baked, before or during Passover. The misinterpretation of the law, on account of the statement She-be-Pessah yesh le-esor kol ha-mazot which occurs in some copies of the Terumat ha-Deshen, was caused by scholars not well versed in the law. The scribe erred in the statement, which should be emended to: Yesh le-esor kol ha-mazah.

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Omer(xiii).1
column2: Q. May the Omer be counted on Friday right after Kiddush, if the latter was said in the synagogue before sunset?

column1: Meir, Viii Passover, Omer(xiii).2
column2: A. The Omer must always be counted after sunset only.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, A Blind Man and Hanukkah Lights(lxxvii).1
column2: A blind man was puzzled whether the object of lighting the Hanukkah candles is to make the historic event public, and since he cannot see, therefore he is not obliged to expose them to others; or since nobody is allowed to enjoy the light of the candles, and the command thereof is just the lighting, must he too light them? He submitted the question to Luria.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, A Blind Man and Hanukkah Lights(lxxvii).2
column2: Q. Is a blind man obliged to light the Hanukkah candles or not?

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, A Blind Man and Hanukkah Lights(lxxvii).3
column2: A. Although the blind man cannot see the light of the candles, yet he must light them because other people can see them. This ruling is deduced from the commandment of zizit, where "seeing" is expressly ordered, and a blind man must observe the law because others can see the garment. Therefore, if the blind man lives with other people who light the Hanukkah candles, it is best that he participate with them in buying the candles, whereas they say the benediction. If he is married his wife should light the candles for him; and if he has no wife and lives by himself, he must light the candles with someone to help him. For the blind man is obliged to observe all the laws of the Torah. Otherwise he might be regarded as excommunicated.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).1
column2: Q. What are the rules governing the Hanukkah candles?

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).2
column2: A. The candles should be lit between sunset and the end of shopping time; never later than midnight. No meal is to be eaten nor any study engaged in until after the candles have been lit. On Friday the candles should be lit in the synagogue before the afternoon prayer. If the lights have been extinguished they need not be relit, except on Friday. The lights should not be used for any purpose whatsoever, but if once extinguished they may be relit for personal use.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).3
column2: The lighting of the candles by the head of the household is sufficient for the entire family. Yet, strictly religious people light a candle for each member of the family, and the still more pious add a candle every day and a candle for every member of the family.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).4
column2: A man who remains in a hotel as a guest, whose family lights the candles at home, must light them without saying the benedictions. A son-in-law living with his wife's parents should light his own candles in his bedroom.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).5
column2: The candles should be placed near the doorway, not higher than ten palms from the floor and not lower than three. They should be lit from left to right. In the synagogue the candles should be put in the candlestick, placed at the south wall, and lit from left to right.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).6
column2: The benediction should be recited before the candles are lit. After the lighting of the first candle, Ha-nerot halalu should be said while the rest are kindled, by other members of the family if desired. One candle may be lit with another, but if the shamash has been extinguished it should not be relit with a Hanukkah candle.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).7
column2: A house that has two entrances does not require lights at each entrance. Old earthen candlesticks should not be used. Olive oil or any other kind of oil may be used instead of candles. Wax should be used in preference to tallow. It would be proper to buy the wax of drippings of the candles in the synagogue; the money should then be donated to charity. One should be careful not to buy the wax drippings of candles in gentile churches for this purpose. Although these may be bought for commercial use, it would be repugnant to use them for the Hanukkah lights.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).8
column2: The Sabbath candles have preference over the Hanukkah candles.

column1: Meir, X Hanukkah, Rules Governing Hanukkah Lights(lxxxv).9
column2: (An abstract from "Yam Shel Shelomoh")
